reviewText:
It feels a bit redundant for me to recommend this game to people, but then again why shouldn't I do it over and over again and again.

Do you like FPSes?  Do you like RPGs with character and equipment upgrade systems, as well as pseudo-magic systems?  Do you enjoy multiple game paths?  Conspiracies?  Futuristic settings?  Stealth gameplay?  If you answered yes to any two of those.... Get. This. Game.

Deus Ex is a classic, in the sense that it is a huge milestone for PC gaming overall.  It seamlessly blends FPS and RPG elements of the day into a combined experience which resonated so well it became a standard in itself.  Newer games like Borderlands, Fallout 3/New Vegas, the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, even Oblivion and Skyrim use much the same formula.  Deus Ex may not be the origin of that formula, but it is definitely one of the better implementations of it.  Dozens of games have tried and failed to recreate that balance of elements... sadly including some of the Deus Ex sequels.

What makes this game get such a strong recommendation from me though is the replay value.  Quite simply the game is so densely packed with content and secrets that you can have played the game for literally years and completely miss certain bits of dialog or secrets.  Add to that the alternate playthrough methods opened up by carrying different weaponry, investing in different skills, selecting different augmentations, and its easy to see why the concept of spending years playing this game is not far-fetched at all.  Don't let my apparent play-time fool you; I've had the game since it was originally released, and if Steam counted that play-time it would be in the thousands of hours.

In short, if you don't have it already, get this game.  Play it once.  Maybe it play it again.  Then, once you're hooked, get a mod that enhances and/or fixes the game and play it again.  Repeat for the next 1-3 years of your life at a minimum.  The last part is likely not optional once you complete the first two steps.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If I had to go back to my teenage years and choose one, and only one, game that shaped my mindset and outlook on the world at large, it would be a close contest with Deus Ex and System Shock 2.

Deus Ex is eerily more relevant today than it has ever been - released in the summer of 2000 and writing this review with the hindsight of 15 years, in-game you won't see the World Trade Center in the New York skyline, you'll read newspapers about martial law being declared in the United States, and deal with a global oligarchical conspiracy that intends to cull the population of the planet through a controlled epidemic. The themes and ideas presented in Deus Ex are not for the light of heart, and perfect for the skeptic and those that realize that what you're presented with on the evening news is anything but the whole, true, real picture. All the world's a stage, and Deus Ex illustrates that magnificently.

Deus Ex is an arguably timeless video game that transcends the medium into something much more than a way to spend a few hours shooting bad guys. It is a thought provoking and radical experience that changed my life, much as a masterfully written novel would.

It's time for my 3-4 year annual playthrough. Why contain it?

reviewText: A stealth rpg fps cyberpunk epic if ever such a thing existed. Deus Ex does what few games do, blend so many genres together in a meaningful way within its game world. The story works perfectly pulling no punches and drawing you deeper away from the reality you perceieve and towards alternative future where everyone comes with a question and not all have answers. The characters are well written and heartfelt and the choices you make impact gameplay in so many ways. The gameplay itself however is heavily stealth emphasised and the areas can get confusing so be prepared to bring up a walkthrough for some of the different areas. Overall, Deus Ex is a gem so far ahead of its time it almost seems modern.

reviewText:
Deus Ex is a stand out classic, a statement hard to argue with. The sheer amount of player agency is a testament to how well the developers accommodated a wide variety of playstyles. Your character is your character alone, with many choices in both skills and augmentations this game offers gameplay diversity that is very rarely seen. Combat is interesting, using modular health meaning taking damage in different areas of your body will vary in negative effects like reduced aim in the arms. This isn't limited to you, as it also effects npcs, for example striking a npc in the lower back with a melee weapon will rendered them unconscious (baton) or dead (knife) in a single hit.

Moving away from gameplay/combat, the story and pacing is generally great, however it seems far to rushed come the last quarter of the game. Sure the illuminati aspect seems overused today in popular culture, but this doesn't detract from the overall enjoyment of the story. Finally the music is absolutely fantastic with great sound design adding immersion to the world.

Overall Deus Ex is a fantastic game, it has aged considerably, from the outdated control scheme and sometimes idiotic ai, Deus Ex still holds up as an enjoyable experience with an enduring legacy, very much worth playing.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rVbPw-Mfujc

After almost 15 years, the legacy of this game still live strong, there are many games that follow the step of the original Deus Ex like a whole feature, games like Bioshock, S.T.A.L.K.E.R, Dishonored and also the new sequels Human Revolution and Mankind Divided, but...

Does this game still hold up?

Getting over the ugly graphics by today standards, bad voice acting, not so good stealth, RPG and Shooting gameplay, this one still a badass game.

Why?

The level desing is so superb that even today I still find new ways to finish a level, it serve all the short coming that the mechanics have, is so open that you can roleplay in this game, is so complex that can feel like a good level from a 90´s FPS and you can beat those levels without killing anyone.

The Story is complex and a fun ride, if you are a sucker for Cyberpunk fiction this is one of the best tales of the genre, it goes over the cheesy dialogue and the sometimes hilarious execution, to deliver a fun tale, fun in a Cyberpunk 2020 RPG Module.

The Music and the art direction, make me forget about the ugly graphics, to the point that sometimes I get so inmerse that I can stop playin until I find a to rest (in game), the levels seems so livable (I don´t know if that a word) that I sometimes seem myself care about the nameless soldiers and goons, I feel bad for them.

In the end, the awnser is yes, even in 2015 there are no game that match this one in my opinion, there are many that came close, but at this time, this one still the second coming of Christ.

ALL HAIL J.C DENTON.

10/10 would crash again.

reviewText:
Some of my friends would say that writing a review for Deus Ex just seems stupid. People already know how good this game is right? They don’t need me to be badgering them to play it! But the sad truth is that as the younger demographic come onto the scene, this is one of those gems that they are missing. And can we really blame them? Just one look at the screenshot or the gameplay on YouTube is enough to tell you that this is not a pretty looking game! Is it really worth getting in 2015?

What Deus Ex provides is a lot of mechanical depth. There is a lot of freedom in the way you approach things: you can be a ruthless murderer, a hacker, a stealthy assassin… it’s entirely up to you how to approach the situations you encounter in the game. Also the mechanics, with the exception of the awful crossbow (don’t try it) don’t feel all that dated. Upgrading your abilities and the various augmentations you can make to yourself is implemented really well to the game, and feels quite modern. What I will warn you about though is that you should not expect to be able to shoot accurately when you start the game. If you don’t put points into pistols then you are going to suck with pistols – it’s annoying but mechanically it makes a lot of sense. After all, in order to shoot accurately you have to be a skilled shot!

Unfortunately it does look terrible, which is the point that I’m going to put the challenge on you as the reader to make the decision. This is one of the best PC games of all time, that’s a fact. If it was released nowadays with modern graphics it would be winning awards. So if you think you can cope with the outdated graphics, then I challenge you to play this game. I advise that in the opening section of the game you put those points into pistols and stick to the shadows to begin with. But if you can get through that opening level, then you are in for a treat – because this game is fantastic.

Please do feel free to comment if you’ve tried and you get stuck or whatever. Or if you were able to break through the graphics barrier and are enjoying arguably one of the finest narrative experiences ever created. I’d love to hear the feedback.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Deus Ex is one of the best accidents I have ever tripped over.  I received this title as software bundle when I bought a video card, back in my early days of building rigs.  I had no idea what it was, but my roommate at the time said he had heard good things.  Boy was I in for a treat.

Deus Ex is (yep, still is) the pinnacle of you picking whatever way you want to achieve your objective.  On top of that, you get conflicting objectives, forcing you to choose your path; thus shaping the game into one of three outcomes.  Sometimes it’s easy to get lost exploring the alternate routes you didn’t take on the way to an objective; it’s that engrossing.

You are given a wide variety of skills, powers (cybernetic augmentations), tools, and weapons to go about your business; more choices to shape your gameplay.  As you play through you’ll get “skill points” (just another unit of RPG exp), and pick up “augmentation canisters” to establish your superhuman abilities.  You can even get upgrade modules for the weapons (silencers, lasers, etc.).

To tie it altogether is a polished cyberpunk atmosphere with a well-written narrative.  The graphics limitations of the time are compensated for by legit voice acting, and AI behavior that’s impressive for the time it was released.

A testament to this title is how the fan community has produced patches to maximize its performance on modern systems.  It makes playing it all over again that much more fun…over a decade later.  It is far better than its sequel (garbage), and still better than its flashy (but still good) prequel.

Now, for the paltry price offered, why on earth would you not pick this up?
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A game that holds up well over time -
Deus Ex is a first person RPG/action hybrid that tells an engaging story about conspiracy and world domination in the future. For its age, the voices, music, and environments are quite good. All of the levels are thoughtfully designed, with freedom to allow the player to consider multiple ways to complete them, and it provides direction without the hand-holding found in some more modern games.

Its only major flaw is graphics, which weren't particularly impressive even when the game was new. There are user-created mods that can significantly improve this, but it is still within the limitations of the engine.

If you are able to ignore the outdated graphics, this game will leave a lasting positive impression on you.

reviewText:
After almost 5 months of crawling through dark sewers, rummaging through the pockets of dead men, not cleaning my house and being late for work on several occasions, I completed the epic adventure and moral journey that is... Deus Ex.

Even though it was released way back in 2000, and had never been considered pretty, I'd found that most well honed gamers still revered Deus Ex as a quintessential, almost religious-like, gaming experience... something I'd never experienced before (in anything.)
So, sometime around the beginning of the year, I crawled into the skin of one J.C.Denton, spy guy.

Deus Ex wasn't a difficult game for me (especially set on 'easy'), but it was challenging.  To spill blood or not to spill blood? (I'm a natural born spiller.) Should I  help the crazy lady find her cat? (I didn't.) Am I to go east or west? (I usually just turned left.) Will these decisions make a difference, somehow? *shrug*
Deus Ex  was a game of Nerves and Patience and Decisions... and bullets.
But, especially, Decisions.. which, by game's end, had become pretty monumental.
Yeah, I really can't say that I had heaps-o'-fun playing Deus Ex. Sometimes it felt long and grueling. Or dark and oppressing.
But, then, that's how it is, when something is intelligent and thought provoking.  And that's why I kept playing, because.. well, it was the object of the game.  I felt that, if I could make it to the end, I might, somehow, come out better than when I started.

And, I think I did.

reviewText: Difficult at times, easy when you master it, an rpg that went on to influence games like fallout. A great fpsrpg, unique, but NOT an fps. DO NOT BUY THIS if you want a run'n'gunner. Heavy emphasis on stealth (can kill nobody if you want) or you can go in guns blazin, but the aiming system isn't as simple as point and shoot. Accuracy is based on skill level, and... you'll get used to it.\n\nIf you're open minded and ready to learn a great game, this story and gameplay is second to none. If you are looking for another half life, then keep looking.

reviewText:
I played this game as a ten year old in 2004, when it was comparatively new, after someone installed it on one of our school computers. I bought it during a summer sale nearly a decade later and got really, really into it. All the characters look the same, aiming is a pain, it -never- autosaves and the stealth elements are clumsy at best. This game should be horrible – but somehow, it isn’t.

In fact, Deus Ex is one of, if not the, best game(s) that I’ve ever played. If you like games with a strong sense of setting, it’s a must-play. The dark, filthy cities and the gritty techno music give you the feeling of a world that doesn’t have much time left. The developers also did a superb job at creating a world that feels fun to explore – there are plenty of (actually interesting) secrets to find, and many opportunities for sequence breaking.

The dialogue is sharp, analytical and often thought-provoking, characters get philosophical at the drop of a hat and the plot manages to tie most famous conspiracy theories from the last century or so together without falling apart. J.C. himself is also really suave and charismatic despite looking at least twenty years older than his given age, kind of like a mix of Dirty Harry, Rick Deckard and Neo. All in all it's a very satisfying experience. They simply don’t make them like this anymore.

P.S.: The Shifter mod improves some of the game's minor flaws and also adds secret weapons.

Accuracy is based on skill level, and... you'll get used to it.\n\nIf you're open minded and ready to learn a great game, this story and gameplay is second to none. If you are looking for another half life, then keep looking.

Not 3 minutes into the game I had found an exploit in the security bot's pathfinding in level 1.
Several minutes go by with me walking my new pet security bot around the first level killing everyone for a non-lethal playthrough.
Shortly after eliminating everyone aboveground, I attempt to take my hungry pet into an underground portion of the level; crashing the game as it tried to unload my poor pet for optimization reasons most likely.

Well the game hard crashed within 10 minutes, that's a fair bit longer than most games I play.

10/10 would crash again.

reviewText:
Do yourself a favor and buy this game if you're even slightly interested. Absolutely incredible game. Timeless level design and story,

Pros
+ Absolutely tons of customization options; with such variety, few people can really boast that they have played the same game twice
+ Narrative is both mature and showcases an impressive amount of depth
+ Augmentations, also, offer great freedom in character tailoring; some are arguably more useful than others, but overall the sense of freedom inherent in this mechanic does well to complement the same freedom found throughout the rest of the game
+ Modular damage; limbs and body parts experience damage separately, and this translates competently to gameplay (eg. taking too much damage in a leg will result in poor movement)
+ The player is offered spectacular freedom in how level objectives and advancement are to be handled
+ Level design is applaudable; everything flows well from one area to another, and layouts are generally sensible
+ Soundtrack is absolutely fantastic; sets the mood, doesn't necessarily distract, and stays with you when the game is off
+ Dialogue and writing is absolutely superb; this is easily one of the better aspects of the game, and it presents well even today

Cons
- Speed/compatibility issue; this may not affect everyone, but there is an issue with compatibility on modern machines which causes overall gamespeed to increase drastically (there is a workaround, but it's something of a hassle to fix)
- Visuals and animations really show their age; these don't hold up well today, but it's not bad enough to detract from the overall experience
- Voice-acting, though it can be quite good, is a mostly underwhelming effort; some voice actors go as far as to be terrible

reviewText:
This is by far one of the best games I have ever played. Not only did the games scenes and backgrounds look great, but the dialogue is incredible. The whole design together really gives the feel of a dystopian future of the USA and the whole world where politics, businesses, and corporations rule all.

The story is definitely the strong point. You play as JC Denton, a nano augmented agent of UNATCO, formed to fight terrorists after the bombing of the Statue of Liberty. You uncover conspiracy theories and many other ideals from all over the world and travel to uncover the truth. While I played I actually really felt the story coming to life and wondered if this was the same way our world was headed.

If you enjoy shooters while getting an RPG elemnt, I highly recommend this. Its a beautiful gem from the minds of Warren Spector and Ion Storm.

reviewText:
Deus Ex desenvolvido pela Ion Storm e dirigido pelo seu idealizador inicial, ninguém menos que Warren Spector, mente por trás de jogos como  System Shock e Thief, além de vários outro títulos aclamados no currículo. Diz-se que Spector depois de desenvolver System Shock, estava cansado da temática de fantasia e ele queria algo mais contemporâneo, algo mais atual. Com isso ele teve uma ideia: porque não usar todas essas teorias da conspiração esparramadas por aí? Warren usando essas diversas teorias da conspiração criou uma amarração mirabolante entre elas, unindo tudo isso a um gameplay e dando corpo a uma criação cyberpunk de altíssimo nível, chamada Deus Ex.

Deus Ex, inicia-se colocando o jogador na pele do agente JC Denton um agente secreto da UNATCO (The United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition) que apesar de humano, tem capacidades especiais devido a implantes nanotecnológicos. A agência de Denton, lhe dá a missão de encontrar seu irmão Paul Denton (também agente da UNATCO), em um pier aos pés da decapitada estátua  liberdade  que por sua vez lhe dá seu primeiro objetivo oficial: interrogar o líder terrorista do grupo de maior ameaça a paz do momento a  NSF (National Secessionist Forces)  que além de ser responsável por arrancar a cabeça da estátua tomou seu interior como base. Daqui em diante sem, mais detalhes da história, pois seria uma injustiça estragar essa trama cheia de intrigas, reviravoltas e as mais diversas conspirações possíveis.

Mais Deus Ex não é só história e conspiração, outro ponto de igual destaque, é a jogabilidade incrivelmente livre e adaptável ao estilo do jogador. Apesar de ter um objetivo fixo, como o jogador irá alcançá-lo fica a critério do mesmo. Por exemplo, imagine uma porta trancada pela qual você tem que passar, ela é protegida por câmeras que ao avistarem você fazem com que uma metralhadora abra fogo contra você, além disso temos dois guardas patrulhando a porta do lado de fora. Difícil entrar? Depende de você e de suas aptidões. Você é um mestre em destrancar portas e quer evitar confronto? Então esguie-se pelas sombras e use um lockpick para abrir a porta. Você é um hacker? Hackeie um computador e faça com que as metralhadoras atirem nos guardas eliminando-os e deixando o caminho livre para que assim você possa pegar a chave de um dos corpos. Você é adepto da força bruta? Deixe um guarda inconsciente com uma pancada na nuca  e pegue a chave de seu bolso tranquilamente. Além dessas temos várias outras maneiras, além de quase sempre se ter rotas alternativas.

Juntando esses elementos citados acima, com uma trilha sonora muito bem trabalhada e dublagens espetaculares, Deus Ex consegue fazer o jogador mergulhar em seu universo e se sentir realmente na pele do agente Denton.
Acho que um único ponto que pode acabar afastando alguns jogadores é justamente o ponto que fez o jogo se tornar tão aclamado que é sua história que pode ficar chata, aos menos aficionados por ficção e teorias do gênero.


Enfim, descrevi apenas alguns pontos principais do que é esse grandioso clássico, o porque dele ser um clássico, só você jogando pra entender. Deus Ex é tão complexo que e até difícil descrever. Não é nem um jogo que vale muito a pena ser destrinchado em review, afinal é o tipo de jogo que merece ser jogado no escuro, é do tipo que cada jogador merece experimentar a sua maneira, tendo o prazer de interpretar, viver, jogar, se iludir e se surpreender com cada novo ponto apresentado, com cada reviravolta, com cada conspiração e com cada conspiração dentro das conspiração.

Deus Ex é um título praticamente perfeito no que oferece em sua proposta, é um jogo que certamente não agrada a todos, mais certamente agrada a grande maioria e basta jogar um pouco pra perceber porque se tornou o clássico que é. Recomendo fortemente.

Joguem e se surpreendam.

Postado originalmente em:   RPG Players[www.rpg-players.com]

reviewText:
Its storyline is gripping, the environment rich, a lot of people to talk to, many sidequests to solve.
You can choose how to complete a level (melée, infiltration, sniping etc.) and combine all of those.
The development of Your capabities is three-fold: You can level up Your skills, aquire augmentations (special powers) and get weapon modifications - some of these You can combine to some degree (e.g. You can get temporary weapon skill increase by using an aug instead of increasing the weapon skill), so combining them intelligently definitely will give You an edge on the field.
The setting itself is futuristic cyberpunk world, full of conspiracies, where the protagonist have to try his best to staly alive and further the agenda of one group or another - because in Deus Ex Your choices have consequences, and these may not be readily apparent.
A 1000 Kudos to the creators, May Your BioEnergy Never Deplete!

reviewText:
I think this is a good representation of how amazing this game is: The people that wrote negative reviews are not PC gamers. Whatsoever. They simply couldn't get past the first level.

You simply cannot dislike this game.

There's reasoning behind this. This game ends up the way you want it to be. Murder those terrorists? Go right ahead. Render them unconcious? Sure. But those are common staples of the stealth genre. What about failing your objectives? A certain mission comes to mind. I won't spoil anything, but there is a mission regarding hostage rescue. Most games would make you reload if you cause the kidnappers to kill the hostage. Not Deus Ex. No, you evac in your chopper and are forced to deal with the consequences. This game turns out exactly how you want it to.

Most games have you set as a predetermined character. You're Batman, or Steve, or Recker. But with Deus Ex, you're who you want to be. You want to be a master of stealth, picking off enemies strategically and becoming invisible when sighted? Cool. You want to master Technology, turning enemies' turrets against them, and using security cams to scout up ahead?You can do that. You want to be a tank, running into a room full of guards, guns ablazing, with no clue what might be up ahead, shooting down anything that makes your crosshair turn red, and then some? Thats fine too. You aren't looking through a character's eyes, you are looking through your own.

The loacations are another matter altogether. You end up visiting the same location three separate times, but every visit you find something new. Your set of objectives is completely different every visit. It doesn't feel repetative, it feels new. You might need to go through the same alley,but you are looking for different things. Things you didnt notice the first time around. It may be the same atmosphere, but there's fresh air every time. The locations you visit only once makes you wish you visited them more. Every time you leave, you wonder if there were secrets you missed, or important items to collect. Everytime the cinematic plays of your helicopter flying away, you just have to wonder of you really did look around every corner, or through every sewer tunnel(yeah, sewer tunnels)

Reviews are a bad way to describe this game, as each person's experience is completely unique. I cannot stress how amazing this game is.

10/10 Everything

reviewText: This is Deus Ex. Not only one of the greatest games ever made but, in my humble (but well judged) opinion, the best game ever made. Deus Ex is an experience no gamer should miss and to me the defining moment of PC gaming. It may never be surpassed. 10/10

Most games have you set as a predetermined character. You're Batman, or Steve, or Recker. But with Deus Ex, you're who you want to be. You want to be a master of stealth, picking off enemies strategically and becoming invisible when sighted? Cool. You want to master Technology, turning enemies' turrets against them, and using security cams to scout up ahead?You can do that. You want to be a tank, running into a room full of guards, guns ablazing, with no clue what might be up ahead, shooting down anything that makes your crosshair turn red, and then some? Thats fine too. You aren't looking through a character's eyes, you are looking through your own.

The loacations are another matter altogether. You end up visiting the same location three separate times, but every visit you find something new. Your set of objectives is completely different every visit. It doesn't feel repetative, it feels new. You might need to go through the same alley,but you are looking for different things. Things you didnt notice the first time around. It may be the same atmosphere, but there's fresh air every time. The locations you visit only once makes you wish you visited them more. Every time you leave, you wonder if there were secrets you missed, or important items to collect. Everytime the cinematic plays of your helicopter flying away, you just have to wonder of you really did look around every corner, or through every sewer tunnel(yeah, sewer tunnels)

Reviews are a bad way to describe this game, as each person's experience is completely unique. I cannot stress how amazing this game is.

10/10 Everything

reviewText: If you are a fan of RPG, FPS, or stealth games you NEED to play this. Deus Ex is up there with Bethesda's games in terms of sheer freedom of play. Wanna be stealthy? Go for it. Wanna go balls to the wall guns blazing? No problemo. There's also hacking, lock picking, nano augmentation, hiding bodies, dialog options, multiple endings, you name it. This game was stupidly ahead of its time. Even the story is eerily conspiratorial and prophetic. A dystopian cyberpunk future where global governments use surveillance and engineered pandemics as population control. Did I mention the game predicted the destruction of the WTC at the hands of a terrorist organization? in the year 2000.\n\nNow with that being said, this is an old ♥♥♥ game with wonky shooting and dated graphics. Essential mods you will need to maximize your enjoyment of this undisputed classic include - BioMod, HDTP, and the New Vision Mod.

reviewText:
Total 'effin classic. Period.

You have an epic conspiracy tale that draws heavily upon Cyberpunk themes , like a blend of the X-Files and William Gibson's Neuromancer. Crazy rogue A.I.s? Check. Illuminati style conspiracies with century old roots? Check. Alien Autopsies in the basement of top secret military installations? Check.

It's an FPS primarily but with a heavy dose of RPG. You will be finding and unlocking upgrades for both your characters augmented abilities and your weapons. This allows you to enhance your character towards the prefered path you take through the game. Whether you hack, stay in the shadows, or go guns blazing you'll find an element of the levels to meet your needs. Choice is the word, and for the most part every choice is fleshed out very well. However, gunplay is a bit wonky without enhaning your aim abilities, but for those worried stealth is really well done and feels fair. Nothing beats hacking a turret into killing the guards for you though.

reviewText: They don't make games like this anymore. It is exceptionally well-written in every single detail. At first it's funny how it manages to incorporate all the popular conspiracy theories, and it becomes frightening when they all turn out to be true. The way people are kept in line with constant terror alert, the shoot-on-sight cops, and the artificial plague is a very dark vision of the future, but the events since the release of the game suggest that it may be prophetic. The role-playing elements, and the fully interactive environment provide lots of freedom to the player: in every playthrough one can find new ways to complete an objective and discover new details hidden in unexpected places. It is advised to talk to every NPC for several rounds, because almost all of them have something interesting and potentially useful thing to say. Mirrors are rarely found in games for some reason, but, interestingly, in this one they are abundant (unfortunately the character animations are as horrible as the voice acting). The music is also noteworthy, Straylight Productions composed another great soundtrack after their previous work in Unreal. It's interesting to compare the cover image of this game and its sequels: this one shows the moment of enlightenment, while the others show aggressive thugs.

Few games have captured me so much that every single book and newspaper I see lying around I read. reviewText:
Real conspiracies. Severe consequences. Intense action role-playing.

I played this game for the first time back in year 2001 and later on made either a partial or full replay every 3-4 years. Everytime I was overwhelmed and impressed with the captivating and immerse story that takes you all around the world, compelling characters, screenplay and atmospheric sound environment.
I would spend many hours looking in every corner, putting the pieces back together and digging the story and it's background, discovering secret areas, thinking about philosophical questions hidden between the lines - pretty much embracing Deus Ex. (A huge portion of this was successfully recreated and implemented in Human Revolution!)

Everything about this game is exceptional: moral choices and it's consequences, elastic gameplay, the atmosphere, all the ambiance you can experience. Deus Ex is my best game I have ever played. A diamond of a game (...that aged so well).
Did I mention replay value? Tremendous. Someone mentioned Deus Ex and I reinstalled deciding to not to give up and pushing on till I see the credits. Game from year 2000 won with growing line of brand new titles. Almost 50 hours of quality gameplay and choosing the approach and playstyle I have never tried before. To my amazement I managed to discover two hidden areas and finding them after several replays was a reward.

Trust no one. Question everything" - Play Deus Ex and soak in the atmosphere."

reviewText: Deus Ex's bland graphics, questionable AI and somewhat clumsy gameplay can't hide its age, but its unique mix of first-person action, puzzle and RPG elements with a bold, groundbreaking focus on story and characters changed the landscape, and would signifcantly influence developers for the decade to come, demonstrating that a game can share qualities of film or literature and still be successfull. It's exploration of human nature is still valid now, more than a decade later. If only Ion Storm had replayed this game before making Invisible War... If you're not a graphics aficionado, and don't require the latest in tessellation, filtering, or ambient occlusion to have an engaging experience, Deus Ex may be worth your time. If you don't know what any of those are, this is even more likely the case. Being a prequel with some of the same characters, Human Revolution also draws many call-backs (or forwards") to this game."

reviewText: Deus Ex's bland graphics, questionable AI and somewhat clumsy gameplay can't hide its age, but its unique mix of first-person action, puzzle and RPG elements with a bold, groundbreaking focus on story and characters changed the landscape, and would signifcantly influence developers for the decade to come, demonstrating that a game can share qualities of film or literature and still be successfull. It's exploration of human nature is still valid now, more than a decade later. If only Ion Storm had replayed this game before making Invisible War... If you're not a graphics aficionado, and don't require the latest in tessellation, filtering, or ambient occlusion to have an engaging experience, Deus Ex may be worth your time. If you don't know what any of those are, this is even more likely the case. Being a prequel with some of the same characters, Human Revolution also draws many call-backs (or forwards") to this game."

reviewText: Deus Ex is personally my favorite game of all time, as even over a decade later, its story and gameplay hold up as some of the finest amoung all video games. The story is one of intrigue, as the main character JC Denton finds himself a pawn in the schemes of the numerous powers to control mankinds destiny and must unravel the conspiracies that truely move the world. With ideas of globalization, corporate power, and internet monitoring playing prominent roles, Deux Ex ends up even more relavant today with its almost prophetic themes. In terms of gameplay, while some aspects might feel slightly cluncky, it still allows for some of the most freedom in accomplishing objectives, from stealth, diplomacy, and long range gunning to barging in guns blazing and even running past bosses. In both these aspects of story and gameplay, Deus Ex is unmatched and is a required at least one playthrough from anyone.

reviewText:
There's not much I can say in my review that hasn't been said in the other positive reviews on here. Deus Ex is a first person shooter/RPG hybrid, regarded by many as the best game ever made. Is it? In my opinion, no, but it is still a great game. If you've played System Shock or Vampire The Masquerade: Bloodlines, you should feel right at home here.

Let's get a few of the 'bad' things out of the way first, the things I've seen a lot of people ♥♥♥♥♥ and moan about on here and on Metacritic. First off, yes the game is ugly. Look at the screenshots before you buy it. If you don't like how it looks, then don't buy it, simple. The graphics are bad, the character models are fairly wooden, and the voice acting is so bad it's good. Oh, and the default key bindings are pretty bad. But you know what? You can re-map the keys. So it's really a non-issue.

Onto the good stuff. This game focuses a lot on inventory management. It's like an old RE title, or Diablo II, where you have only so much room in your inventory for items. So you'll constantly be wondering if it's worth it to carry around the huge flamethrower or keep a couple of pistols and a sword; personally I find this a great change in pace from some games that just let you carry around everything.

The sheer level of character customization is crazy. You get skill points, but only at certain points; you gain nothing from defeating enemies, unlocking doors, etcetera. When you find a secret room or explore a certain area, you get skill points, and you get them from completing objectives. Then its up to you where to put them. Pistols, rifles, melee combat, explosives, pickings locks, swimming, healing, and more. You can't master them all (withoug exploting a bug late game) so you have to manage the skill points wisely. On top of that, you can find countless modifications for your guns, among them recoil, reload speed, range, scopes, and laser sights.

Oh, and and on top of that, you have several slots for augmentations to your body to give you healing power, quicker speed, strength, defense, and more. But you only have so many slots, and the augmentation items you find carry two for one slot. So do you take health regeneration, or an energy shield? There are so many ways to customize the character to your playstyle it is really astounding.

The levels themselves a huge and allow for a variety of routes. In the first mission, I was looking for the person I needed to speak to for my objective; he was to allow me to get into the building where my foes were. Instead I found a big stack of boxes and jumped up on them until I got to the roof, totally bypassing that part of the mission. Later on, if you're careful and look everywhere and make the right decisions, you can even find information to skip entire boss fights.

The story can be a bit on the confusing side, but it's well written and takes into account a lot of different conspiracy theories from the real world. I can't say to much without spoiling it so I'll leave it to you to figure it out.

So should you get this game? Yes, absolutely. For $6.99, it's practically stealing.

reviewText: Deus Ex, despite being released in the summer of 2000, is still one of the greatest role-playing shooter hybrids available on PC. If you're a fan of futuristic settings or the cyberpunk science fiction genre as I am, Deus Ex's storyline and environments should be right up your alley.\nSet in 2052, you take on the role of JC Denton (JC supposedly refers to Jesus Christ) a rookie to an anti-terrorist organization called UNATCO. But things quickly get out of control and you are soon involved in a huge conspiracy involving various factions - including the Illuminati and the Hong Kong Triads, as you travel over the world to unravel this conspiracy.\nThe game allows a great deal of freedom and various choices - you will also have a few multiple endings to achieve. Deus Ex is a branching game, meaning there are always multiple paths to choose from, you could even choose to not kill anyone at all through the entire game - which is a lot more complicated to do than it sounds, trust me!

reviewText: This game is seriously the best game ever made.  It seamlessly merges a captivating story, comprehensive RPG elements, wonderful stealth mechanics, and exciting gun battles.  It's a game that focuses on environment rather than inexplicable yet convenient chest high walls all over the place to take cover behind.  The graphics aren't that great anymore, but if you are looking at a game released in the early 2000's for graphics you are being silly.  Regardless, there are mods you can use to improve them.  Deus Ex set the bar for all RPG FPS games since its release.  It is absolutely worth the cost.

reviewText:
Dues Ex is my favourite video game of all time, there I said it. Even better than Final Fantasy VII, better than Tomb Raider, better than Unreal Tournament, Counter Strike and Command and Conquer. It's like totally awesome.

So how what exactly is so awesome about Dues Ex? Well everything (apart from maybe the graphics).

The Story is truly excellent, an exciting and compelling cyber punk narrative about huge companies conspiring to maximise profits at the expense of peoples lives (sounds far fetched I know)....what's truly great is the game gives you scope as a player to make meaningful choices that affect the story in large, sweeping ways. OK, that's just not true, though the choices in the game feel really significant and weighty, they don't have a large impact on the story itself (for example one choice is the decision between killing an important character in different ways, but ultimately she's toast) but the fact these choices exist was at the time groundbreaking and led to a real sense of investment in the world.

The gameplay is satisfyingly emergent, you have the choice to approach different scenarios like Snowden (by hacking), Clinton (being duplicitious) or Putin (by using overwhelming force) or some combination of the three. This ties into the character you have designed in a very natural way (so you can choose to make a cyber specialist if you love the Matrix, a character who can sneak around like Corvo in Dishonoured or, if your big and stupid like me, just tote a huge rocket launcher around blowing everything to smithereens). This leads to a real sense of creativity and fun as well as giving the game tonnes of replayability as it feels deeply cool to solve the same problem in multiple ways.

The writing of the game is intelligent, and uses sweet science fiction technology like super powerful AI's and cloning to ask questions concering the nature of humanity and consciousness, the trade off between security and liberty (still very relevant in the digital age) and to what extent (if any) we should avoid using lethal force in the fight against terrorists" (an argument which came up recently in UK politics thanks to Corbyn). There's some scenes in the game where JC (the protaganist / antihero) will simply debate concepts like nationalism versus individualism or the tendency of power to corrupt (as in Cicero's famous dictum) and his opponents will present compelling counterarguments of their own (and awesome lines like "God was the dream of good government"). The nuanced
recommended: "grey" tones of these discourses matches the grim cyperpunk pallette of the landscape without descending into nihilism or a feeling of futlity.\n\nThe game even manages to work as a power trip in certain moments as JC can turn invisible
hoursPlayed: set huge ED 209-esque robots against one another and (with the help of an overpowered augment) regenerate his health like you were playing call of duty. Yet at the same time the game (despite what some will tell you) clearly does not want you to play the game like a mindless shooter

votesTotal: the game arguably gets easier as you get through it and the choices are largely illusory. Yet it's clever and engaging

reviewText:
It does not occur often that I start up a game as old as the first installment of Deus Ex, but there are occasions where I'm limited to using my laptop (an underpowered machine I mainly use for programming and typewriting) and take the opportunity to relive the old days. One of those occasions had occurred recently and Deus Ex was my choice at the time.

By many still considered the best PC gaming has to offer, I must say I was surprised how easily I got dragged into this game. Even though the graphics were decent for its time, starting out with a classic like this was a tad hard for me. One cannot ignore the fact that computer screens in overall had a lower resolution back then so these textures and models did look better (that, and expectations were on par with what technologically was possible). However, the combination of most audiovisual aspects and game content blend in perfectly, creating a convincing atmosphere and compelling plot (and worth mentioning is that this plot is a sequel to Deus Ex: Human Revolution). Another thing Deus Ex does right is its gameplay, because even though this isn't advertised as an RPG, it does a better job at being one than, say, Final Fantasy 12. The character development is absolutely rock solid!

When I add all of this up I can only conclude how this game is a masterpiece for its time and still well worth a playthrough today. It's also worth mentioning that there are several mods improving texture and model quality to something more fitting for today's technological level, though I haven't really used any of those.

Verdict: definitely buy. This game offers a lot of content, more than today's standards.

reviewText:
Deus Ex is simply one of the TOP 3 FPS of all time, the others being Half-Life and DOOM.

The reason for such high standard is not the graphics quality, or sound effects or the RPG elements of the game, but the story. This game has a unique story in the game industry.  It makes the gamer keep playing just to see how the story will unveil. It is also possible to reach the goals by various ways, not just the standard go forward and shoot approach. You can approach a goal by sneaking, by finding different paths, or by shooting everything on sight. The last option usually does not work.

There are a few places where you can make a choice that changes the story a bit, and that makes the replayability of the game amazing.

It is a great game to be replayed every year!

reviewText:
This is, and always will be, one of the best and most revolutionary games of all time. It is one of many places where I need to call ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t on metascore, because it deserves more than 90. I would not go as far as to say it deserves a full ace, but about 96-97? Sure.

Back when it came out, it was the biggest deal. Sure, Half-life laid the foundation for FPS games, but this game is no mere FPS. It is an RPG, and an excellent one at that. Comparing it to other old-school RPGs, it would always come out on top for me.

The best feature of this game is, it does not stop you from finding your own solutions to problems. Say there is a laser tripwire that sets of an alarm. You can solve this problem in so many different ways. You can run through and shoot your way through. You can hack the control panel. You can find one of usually at least two ways around it. Or, alternatively, you can stack up some boxes and jump over it. The game will not stop you.

Also, everything you do actually matters. It matters if you go lethal or peaceful, it matters if you talk to people or not, it matters if you explore and it affects the game, and the story. It is up to this day, one of the most sublime non-linear RPGs on the market.

The story is very good, provided you are into conspiracy theories. The hero, JC Denton will struggle with or against UNATCO, the UN, US government, NSF and even the Illuminati. To avoid spoilers, I will just say that the conception is just fantastic, but you need to experience it yourself.

The graphics don't hold up today, unfortunately, but a true connesieur will be able to look past that, as lack of graphical fidelity is the case with many games of the past age. The soundtrack makes up for it, though. This is one of many cases where music from a game is a real piece of art.

You would do yourself a great service if you bought this game and played it to completion. It bears the name of a classic with pride, and does not disappoint. After a little bit of tinkering it will run at 1080p, and the controls are fully customizable, so you should make do with those somewhat clunky mechanics.

It is really that good. And dirt cheap too. Take my word, and pick it up.

Deus Ex gets my 0451/10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I want to tell you a story. It has spoilers, so consider yourself warned.







My JC Denton was a good agent. In the field, he was an intelligent, efficient snipe-happy hacker, with a pistol for emergencies. (Side note: Silenced sniper rifle + laser-sight pistol, both at Advanced skill level =OP.)

However, when he infiltrated the building Paul Denton told him to to show him that UNATCO was corrupt, my JC mixed up his objectives and went to the roof, where the satellite dish he was supposed to change if Paul was correct was located, instead of the basement, where the proof was. This was a bit of a dilemma.

Then my JC Denton had an epiphany.

He realized that he would work for whichever side allowed him to shoot, loot, and hack as much as possible. So right then and there, my JC hacked the satellite dish and looted what was inside, betraying his country for some immediate cheap thrills. Don't get me wrong, he wasn't psychotic; my JC was just extremely vindictive, self-righteous, and challenge-seeking, and he had a lot of guns.

He then went through the rest of the game, shooting and looting and hacking all over the place, and when the time came, he took the only sensible option and merged with Helios.

Deus Ex has a lot of problems. It looks awful, there aren't enough character options for the action-oriented player, the voice acting is atrocious, and some enemies have way too much health (lookin' at you, greasels). However, any game with this amount of player choice and understanding of the player (one time, when lost and trying to leave a cathedral, I walked up to a French chef and JC promptly asked how the hell to get out of there) deserves whatever recommendations it can get.

Seriously though, f*ck all the transgenics.

reviewText:
This game is one of the best videogames ever made. That may sound like a empty statement, but trust me, it isn't. This game is one of the classics and considered to be one of the best games of all time.
But there are some downsides. I mean, really big downsides. Look at Half Life (1998) and then look at Deus Ex (2000). Noticed something? Yeah? Deus Ex looks bad. Really bad. Beyond bad. It's funny that Half Life came out two years earlier and still looks better than Deus Ex 1 does.
The first few Levels (Liberty Island, etc.) are really memorable, but they also may be a tiny bit difficult for newcomers , due to the lack of acquired skills and augmentations.

Okay, so now we're finished talking about the bad parts. But why is this game so good?
Easy. Back in 2000 when we were still afraid of approaching the new millenium, FPSs
were good, and they were getting better all the time (Systemshock2, Half Li...I think you know where I'm going with this). And then Deus Ex came. The gameplay was deep, the plot was thick, the backstory was interesting.
IonStorm did a great Job on trying to create a dark Cyberpunk atmosphere.

So wacha waitin' fo m8? Go buy it! It's good!

reviewText:
Deus Ex was a game released in the year 2000 for the PC and then later was released on the Playstation 2. You play as JC Denton an augmented rookie agent working for UNATCO.

The gameplay takes the form of 1st Person with many Role Playing elements, such as skill points. The game also incorperates narrative paths, and many ways to complete a single objective, an example would be the first mission of the game, your objectives are to rescue a fellow agent and capture a mamber of the Terrorist group, the NSF. This mission you can sneak in by looking for an easier was to get in than the front entrance, or you can just run in and kill everything. It is also possible to access the computer terminals either by retrieving the the log in credentials, or by hacking the terminal. Some terminals allow you to disable cameras, or change who a gun turret may fire at. Referring back to the first mission, you can access a gun turret near the entrance, lure the guards out and watch them get taken out by the turret.

Without spoiling too much, the game takes place in a cyberpunk-esque future of the year 2052, involving conspiricy theories, etc. I won't go further into the story as I feel it is something that needs to be experienced by the player themselves in their own way.

The sound of the game is wonderful, the music is really good, with some tracks that really standout such as UNATCO HQ theme, the Main Theme and many others, the music of the game changes depending on the current situation, such as when you are in combat, the music will change to a more upbeat and urgent rendition of the standard level theme.
Along with the Music of the game, the Voice acting is rather mixed through the game, with some characters being playing incredibly and then others quite poorly, for example, later through the game you arrive at Hong Kong, where you are greeted to stereotypical Asian accents, that may even be consided offensive to some.
The sound effects of this game aren't really overly amazing, they seem rather average, but aren't bad and don't negatively impact the experience.

The game to some may seem quite difficult, as it just throws you in the game and you have to figure a lot out your self. While I prefer this than having my hand held, it's understandable that some may not like out. The highest difficulty of the game, Realistic, is quite difficult in many ways, such as headshots are insta-kills, so you may find yourself dead a lot when spotted, but this is also the same the other way around, headshots are also insta-kills to your enemies too.

Once you have finished the game, I recommend multiple playthroughs of this to experience it multiple ways, however, if you feel like breathing new life into this, then there are some fantastic mods currently out, or in development, here are some of the mods that I myself have used that I think are incredible. I have split them into ones that I feel are fine to use on a first playthrough and ones that I think should be used on subsequent playthroughs.

Fine For First Playthroughs
HDTP -
This mod greatly enhances the models of the game, however, this is only in Beta so some of the models aren't updated which really stand out.
Release 1 - http://www.moddb.com/mods/project-hdtp
Beta (Requires Release 1) - http://offtopicproductions.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=9&t=11566

New Vision -
This mod greatly enhances the textures of this game, this mod has had its final release and will receive no further updates.
http://www.moddb.com/mods/new-vision

DirectX 10 Renderer -
While this mod doesn't change much on by default, it allows you to use to use detail textures, modify FOV, Anti-Aliasing, Anisotropic Filtering, better lighting and improved draw distance. I also get much better performance on this renderer than any of the others out there.
http://kentie.net/article/d3d10drv/

Kentie Deus EXE -
This is an improved launcher for the game that includes loading of mods from their own folders, setting custom resolutions and enabling/disabling GUI scaling, among other features.
http://kentie.net/article/dxguide/index.htm

Subsequent Playthroughs
Shifter -
This mod is a fantastic mod that changes so much, it includes addictional Augmentations, Unique Weapons, Random NPC Inventory, Alt-Fire, Additional Skill System and Better AI.
http://www.moddb.com/mods/shifter1

Deus Ex Revision -
This is a mod that I have only recently started using, it's quite new and still in development, there is a demo of the mod available but the final release is expected some time in 2014, it is a reimagining of the game, it changes the levels of the game, but leaves the story as is. It is nice to go through the game with this mod for the level changes as while it isn't a huge difference, it is nice for the slight changes of the layout and enemy positions.
http://www.moddb.com/mods/deus-ex-revision

Overall I feel that this is a must play game and that it should be played by everyone at least once. I highly recommend this game for anyone.

reviewText:
The best video game of all time, bar none; the sequels Invisible War (horrible game) and Human Revolution don't even come close.

The game takes place in the year 2052 where the world has become a ghetto ravaged by war, terrorism, and disease. A new plague, known as the Gray Death, is spreading rapidly with no cure; only a vaccine known as Ambrosia can prevent infection, and only if you can keep taking it. Worst of all, production is extremely limited and most of it is rationed out to key government and utility workers. You play as UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition) agent J.C. Denton, fresh out of the academy, on his first mission to reacquire a supply of Amrbosia that has been stolen by the terrorist group NSF (National Secessionist Forces). But it doesn't take long to figure out that something much more sinister is going on.

Deus Ex features incorporates conspiracy theries (Illuminati, Trilateral Commission, Knights Templar, Majestic 12, etc) into a well-integrated cyberpunk storyline. It is the most cerebral game I've ever played, which focuses on the ideas of liberty and authority with very intelligent dialogue.

The gameplay is incredible as well. Deus Ex is a FPS/RPG hybrid and the best I've seen in it's genre. You gain skill points that you can invest into different skills, such as Heavy Weaponry, Lockpicking, or Medicine. You also receive nano-augmentations throughout the game that can be toggled on or off at the expense of bioelectrical enegry, such as Quiet Movement or Invisibility.

The only downside to this game, if you want to call it that, is that the graphics are outdated as the game came out in 2000. However, there are lots of mods that improve things like texture quality which make the game more visually pleasing. If you were a PC gamer around the time though (Half Life, Unreal, Tribes, etc) then it shouldn't phase in you the least bit.

Play this game NOW. You're not a real PC gamer if you haven't.

10/10. Such fun. Much wow.

reviewText: A true gem, even by modern-day standards, Deus Ex took me a while to get in to. reviewText:
Alot of people spam this game when you ask them what they consider the best game ever made is, but is it true? Ill toss my opinion in the sea of maymay reviews and BOMBs etc etc

Ill start off with the bad
The gameplay is clunky
The graphics are ♥♥♥♥
The game will most likely run like ♥♥♥♥ without a fanmade patch or fix like DEUSEXE
The voice acting is bad and can have some very bad actors here and there

Now for the good

The voice acting is bad and can have some very bad actors here and there (its one of those wierd quirks in the game that makes it enjoyable and unique, not just a bunch of british people making everything sound dramatic)

The graphics, while bad, have a style to them that I havent seen matched in any other game, not even the subsequent
Deus Exes... its very dirty and cool temperant with all the blues and greys, with vibrant colors sprinkled across the levels to keep it just interesting enough to the eye

The gameplay is indeed garbage, but it has a charm to it as well, it hard to explain and very subjective, but you might find yourself laughing your ♥♥♥ off after you smack a guard in  the back of the head with a baton and he falls flat on his face

The real gem of the game is the story and writting as well as characters and twists in the plot. Its one of those games where you never want to really finish it because its so good, you dont want to see the ending come just yet. Ive reinstalled 3 times already and still havent seen the ending

The level design is very open and large for its time, Im always impressed at how many paths are crammed into the level without being to obvious.

This is a short review, Its my favorite game of all time, it has flaws, but those flaws give it some character. I highly suggest you hop into it if you ever have a weekend to get ingulfed in a game. The first 2 levels arent top tier by any means, so dont let  them drive you off like they made me for awhile.


I played this in 2014, and loved it. So dont believe the very few haters of this game when they say only people who played it when it came out like the game.

reviewText:
You see this cardboard man who looks like he replaced his scalp with a freezer unit and his eyes with lazer pointers? You hear his incredibly inaccurate thick German accent as he complains about a conspiracy by the custodial staff to replace all the soda in the vending machines with Orange flavor instead of Lemon-Lime?

Well you see, he actually thematically represents the possible future plight of being left behind by the world due to physical augmentations becoming rapidly obsolete as new technology replaces it, and you not being upgraded due to the cost and lack of empathy from your superiors. This shatters your self-confidence and renders you irrelevant within society, furthering your frustration and anger that culminates in a hatred for the protagonist whose augmentations far surpass your own. This hate is unleased in the brutal execution of your employer's enemies and finally comes to a head once your unfeeling superiors send you to kill the rogue agent protagonist, fighting more for your own vitriolic feelings rather than for the puppetmasters that care not if you are melted down for scrap like a broken, inoperable machine.

So that's something

reviewText:
Introduction
Deus Ex was produced, published and developed by Ion Storm in June 26, 2000. Regarded as an incredibly influential game of it's time which it is greatly known for it's ability to know players actions, referred to as a breakthrough in emergent gameplay and through experimentation secret dialogues and other rewards unlock, it's art direction, atmosphere and surpisingly, it's scale, intelligent design and humor help deliver an intense, conspiracy-themed world.

Deus Ex's engine was written in the Unreal Engine 1 at the time it was made, housing coloured lightmaps, skeletal animation, sprite-based particle effects and qutie a bit more.

Gameplay
Deus Ex is a hybrid of First Person Shooter and Role Playing elements. Though semi-linear, there is many quests to do in the game which offers a challenge and reward of skill points or weapons/upgrades. These upgrades improve Denton's ability to hack, swim, shoot certain types of weapons, jump higher, regenerate health, deactivate security restrictions such as a locked door to an armory or shop.

Criticisms; Minor
Deus Ex is very clunky gameplay wise, so it will take a bit of time for you to get used to it if you've never played Deus Ex before.

Deus Ex's level design can be confusing.

Gunplay
The gunplay varies, you can use literally everything from Crowbars, Tasers to Rocket Launchers and Turrets (with the help of a skill) to take down enemies or you can use stealth and toss a throwing knife into his throat. Varied in it's approach to pretty much combat or lack of it.

Music
Deus Ex music is focused heavily upon eletronic and classical hybrids. It is dynamic and very beat heavy - influenced in a unique way by the players actions. assualting friendlies will cause the music to be suddenly rough, choatic classic electronica hybrid ochestra (yes, it is THAT good) to a calm, placid ambient drone that heals the ears when visiting the bustling cities when walking around or sneaking.

Graphics
The Unreal 1 engnine was updated in Deus Ex to allow for coloured lightmaps, textured shading, mipmapping, skeletal animation (to include more advanced animations). Though Deus Ex paled in graphics in comparison to other games, the world is still believable and large for it's time. Due to the expandability, the source code and SDK's packaged with Deus Ex, this produced many modifications from graphical, gameplay and to minor changes such as changes to HUD.

Mechanics
Deus Ex uses a 'Skill Point' design to allocated a fixed price of skill points which are earned by doing quests, use of dialogue, clever exploration or by experimenting.

Storyline
Deus Ex revolves around J.C Denton, an officer at UNATCO. UNATCO is an anti-terrorist organisation founded after the Statue of Liberty was blown up by NSF terrorist forces. J.C Denton is sent with his brother Paul Denton to find the plague that haunts civilizations with an atmosphere of death and control. The player finds out more and more about the sinister plague and the lack of Ambrosia, its cure. This leads you, the player into finding out much more than what meets the eye as you find leads all round the world.

Deus Ex awards exploration, inquistiveness and theres tons of hidden content, including story, items, mini-quests and lets you play as if it were an open-world and it gets better from there! Many, many guns to choose from, many ways to play stealthy or violently.

reviewText:
There is no designated order of things to do, whichever direction you take is always the right one! Game is built around exploration but the punishing combat mechanics will see you mashing that quicksave key or lose precious progress to a two second firefight that didn't go in your favor. (Bots that aren't using sniper rifles shouldn't be able to instant kill headshot you.)

They coupled together a magnificent soundtrack with the most hilarious (so bad it's good) voice acting I've heard in quite awhile. Ye olde countable polygons and short drawdistances (complete with fog) reminiscent to the N64 and playstation radiate an unsettling vibe similar to the first couple Tomb Raider games.

Despite an emphasis on multiple interlocking branching paths in each map, thirty hours is quite awhile for the mechanics to start feeling formulaic. It boils down to finding the keys/login information/rockets/lockpicks/hack tools you'll need to open the next door and then pulling up the item or information and punching it in. Augmentations should have been passive and not reliant on yet ANOTHER finite bar of constnatly depleting energy. If you're going to make your game dark as all hell (as opposed to orange) the flashlight shoudln't sap your energy leaving you potentially irrevocably blind. The cache of items you can hold is unforgivably small and the firearms are HORRENDOUSLY IMABLANCED. I put every upgrade onto the assault rifle and it still couldn't carry its own weight. You only need the pistol, crossbow, dragontooth, stun baton, and of course the gep gun.

A masterpiece in it's own time.

Also there's an irritating bug that crashes the game about two thirds of the way in on the frigate escape.

reviewText:
Nano-augmented agents will often encounter stress created by resentment among fellow agents, particularly those who have been mechanically augmented. In an effort to secure freedom and liberty for those under their protection, many UNATCO agents have chosen to sacrifice social acceptance for mission performance by surgically replacing limbs and organs with mechanically or electronically enhanced equivalents. But your nano-augmentations points the way to the future: thousands of microscopic, living, organic machines that exist in symbiosis with your body.

Because such augmentations create only minimal disfigurement, they are likely to be a source of friction between you and other mechanically augmented agents -- but it is important to understand that UNATCO is an organization where individuals must act in concert. Each is important to the whole, and mutual understanding is essential to teams comprised of diverse human and augmented
agents.

If you have any further questions or wish to discuss these issues, please feel free to send email to CarverEschells\UNATCO.4352.768 to make an appointment.

And welcome to UNATCO, agent.

reviewText:
There are games that you play, and then games that you live. Deus Ex (DX1) one falls emphatically into the latter category. If you have never played this game, you have missed out big time. Because video game graphics have advanced so much that the default graphics will make it hard for any new player to play without cringing. However, thanks to moddb.com, you can install a high definition mod that will improve the graphics of the game immensely! (HDTP, New Vision to name a couple. There are even elaborate guides out there to make the graphics great)

The RPG elements in this game were revolutionary. So much realism in the gameplay for a game that was released in 2000. So much thought/philosophy/depth/insight put into the storyline, you would've thought Christopher Nolan had a part to play in writing it; many little details in the game have meaning and consequence; a newspaper lying around, your conversations with people, how much you kill/explore. The music is so well composed it will stay with you long after you have finished the game, more like haunt you. This game will put you in a reminiscing trance. I first played the preview for this game in 2001, then played the full version 2-3 times over until 2008. And after I got my new gaming rig, I played it one final time in May 2014 with all graphical enhancement mods.

I've probably set incredibly high expectations for anyone who has yet to play the game, but it really is the best single-player game I've ever played, and I've played many shooters out there. Just play it with an open mind, knowing that it was a game built more than a decade ago. The AI behavior isn't something to ride home about.

If you played Deus Ex III: Human Revolution and thought that game was brilliant and immersive. That game is a remake of this one in so many ways. DX1 won several game of the year awards, and at least one game of the decade that I know of. All that has got to account for something.

reviewText:
An absolute classic, and far superior to its sequels.

Brilliantly realised future with a fantastic level of detail and actual choice.
Well realised and belivable characters make progressing through the story a real joy.This is really hammered home when compared to the generic and non-fleshed out bad guys of the more recent DE3.
DE also does a good job of not patronising the player. Compare DE's blueprints and compass with DE3's great big *%£$ destination arrow. The fact everything isn't over simplified and handed to you on a plate makes success in DE a far more satisfying affair than it's more pretty but shallow and obnoxious sequels.

The graphics are old and the game can be glitchy, but this does not take away from this real masterpiece of a computer game. I long for a modern iteration that follows the spirit of DE and not just lip service!

reviewText:
Ignore the cheesy cutscene at the start. Ignore the awful graphics, the dodgy AI, the bugs - just bear with it for the first hour. The first few missions are basically tutorials; a prologue establishing the atmosphere, the sense that you're merely a pawn in a larger conflict, and how you want to play the game. Then, the twist comes and your thrust into a world of conspiracy, corruption, and moral ambiguity.

The huge levels and the amount of choices available makes 'Deus Ex' exceptionally replayable also. You may be surprised to find that there are many sandbox elements. There are many areas with large volumes of NPC's who can be toyed with, as well as many hidden nooks and crannies. Exploration will usually reward you with additional story, rare items, or both. Regrettably, these areas only show up after the first mission.

Once you get used to the combat, you'll find it smooth. The abundance of open areas means sniping is possibly the most rewarding option of the game. But there are also flamethrowers, rocket-launchers, grenades that can be turned into mines, plasma-rifles, assault-rifles that can also throw bombs, and a LIGHTSABER (well, it's not called that...but it totally is) Plus you can apply upgrades that turn you invisible, regenerate your health, lift heavy objects, see though walls, deploy a remote-controlled missile, and can make you jump like your in 'The Matrix.'

Of course, 'Deus Ex' is at heart a roleplaying game - even though it has plenty of FPS and stealth elements. Unlike 'System Shock 2,' you can pick up any weapon and use it...but you'll be terrible. You'll move like a drunkard if you pick up a rocket launcher untrained, you'll aim like a drunkard if you try sniping, and you'll hit like a drunkard if you try melee. But you can still pick them up in an emergency. (The only thing you can't do untrained is hack computers.)

'Deus Ex' is bugged, but whilst it may sound odd, it's bugged in a quirky way that only breaks the immersion if you want it to. You can use mines to climb up buildings to reach places your not supposed to get to until later - which often causes NPC's to completely freak out. You can cheat during boss-battles by setting mine-traps, throwing TNT at them mid-conversation, or just running past them. Enemies won't attack you whilst  in the shower out of politeness, and Paris nightclub guards won't care if you murder someone before their very eyes. Finally, you can get the entire Anti-Terrorism squad to attack a vaccum-cleaner. My advice is play the game straight first time, then spend every playthrough afterwards trying to see how you can turn 'Deus Ex' from serious cyberpunk-thriller into hilarious funland.

The recent 'Deus Ex: Human Revolution' is worth your time, but it can't hold a candle to it's grandfather. Whilst it might seem uninuitive and difficult to begin with: stay with it. You will be rewarded with one of the best games ever made.

reviewText: There's a cliché about this game being re-installed every time it's mentioned. That's very nearly true for me because I can't even remember how many times I've re-installed this game. I never played it until it was almost 10 years old and woefully out of date graphically but, man, this game blew me away. The freedom of choice, the sense of exploration,  the atmospheric setting, and the awesome old-school tracker music all come together to make this game an unforgettable experience. It isn't perfect (mainly because of the terminally stupid and nearsighted AI), but it sure comes close.

reviewText:
i had just beaten the game. it was amazing, there is (with an exception of a few games) NOTHING that comes close to what this game has achieved. even with its faults, this is one of, if not the greatest games i have ever played. this game proves that even with faults, you can still achieve something so stellar.

i am currently undergoing my second playthrough of the game on realistic difficulty with the mods New Vision (makes the games' environments look pretty) and Shifter (adds things that should have been in the game in the first place and fixes allot of bad things in the game), and by god, it is even better. i have currently already poured about 8 hours into the game on my second playthrough, and i am only on the THIRD MAIN MISSION. this game has so much to offer if you go looking for it.

on top of that, every decision you make changes the game, from the big things, even to the tiniest detail. for example you can go into the girls bathroom and then get yelled at, and when you go meet up with your boss later on, he will tell you to be careful and stay out of the girls bathroom. but big things can even change what you will do in the next mission.

every pretty much playstyle is available in this game. for example so far i haven't killed anyone, and i have mostly relied on melee weapons, but i also have a minicrossbow tranq gun with me. you can be the ruthless killer who kills with nothing but the objects in his hands, or you can be the guy with the silent gun. but you can also be the guy who just wants to go in guns blazing (but it wont be easy), or the guy who picks off enemies from a distance. be who ever you want, where ever you want, whenever you want. mind you, this is not an easy game.



so go. go and buy this game. you will not regret it.

reviewText:
This game is the best game of all time. The story is deep and draws from major conspiracy theories (Ex. Illuminate,Chupucabra, The Mothman). As you progress through the game you will gather skill points. All skills have 4 levels:
Untrained
Trained
Advanced
Master
The game is very balanced, until you get a master skill in weapons. You see as you progress in weapons the changes are noticeable but not tremendously game changing, but... once you hit master in a weapons category.... you are GOD. My pistol (as long as I am aiming at somebody) can't miss. I have put 4 accuracy mods (each pumping up the accuracy by 2% I think) and all I have to do is aim above the torso and everybody DIES. There are many skills to talk about, such as lockpicking and bypassing electronics. You can open any door and bypass any alarm as long as you have enough multitools (electronic lockpicks) and enough lockpicks (well um... not-electronic lockpick). But a person who is not trained in the lockpicking and elctronics skills will leave more broken lockpicks and shorted out multitools than a minecrafter leaves behind broken pickaxes and shovels. So investing in those skills is not necessary but it really helps (but a word to the wise NEVER INVEST IN SWIMMING THERE WILL NEVER BE A TIME WHERE SWIMMING IS REQUIRED TO GET TO A OBJECTIVE! IT IS A VERY STUPID IDEA!) However by far the best part about this game is that it has more freedom of choice than any other game out there. There are literally hundreds of ways to solve a objective. Let's say you need to recover sensitive data about your organization.What do you want to do? Do you want to equip your trusty plasma rifle (heavy weapons) and go in guns blazing, or do you want to sneak in and quietly neutralisethe guards, or how about you hack that computer you didn't even know about and flood the entire building with lethal amounts of radiation then equip a hazmat suit and grab the data without ever pulling the trigger, or maybe you bribe that terrorist guard you didn't even know had dialouge and have him gat the data for you. Well what do you choose, I mean you don't have to, you can find your own way in (THAT DOESN'T INVOLVE SWIMMING NICK!) because there are definetly more options that I haven't found yet. Okay you got the data and you ar eleaving the area WHEN SUDDENLY! The terrorist leader appears! As far as you know he is a very bad guy! He has killed friends of yours before and he will probably do so again! He asks for the data and he will kill your brother if you don't give it to him! Now it appears that there are only two options, BUT WHAT YOU DIDN'T KNOW EAS THAT AFTER YOU MAKE YOUR DECISION IN THAT BRIEF TIME THAT HE WAS HEADING TO HIS CAR... you could put a bullet straight through the back of his head. You know the dozen armed men that he broght with him will be SUPER ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if you did that, but hey you are super badass JC Denton you probably have a way out of this predicament already... or maybe you never got into that situation at all.....

reviewText:
I cannot recommend a game more highly than this one. The adage that whenever anyones mentions Deus Ex you have to re-install it is true, and there is a reason for it. The argument that it is simply nostalgia that keeps people playing holds no ground.

While the graphics and AI haven't exactly stood the test of time the rest of the game does not pull any punches or treat the player as if they are anything but smart. The story is deep and long and worth telling. The gameplay is RPG told through the first person perspective, and it refelcts accordingly. Your abilities are limited but progress to your desires.

The dystopian cyberpunk vibe is both exhilerating and creepy at the same time. The feeling of 'Oh man I hope the future is this cool' is balanced with, 'Could it really get this bad?' This is the best PC game ever.
