reviewText:
The 1990's culminated in three monumental titles that undeniably would shape the FPS adventure genre for years to come: Half Life (1998), System Shock 2 (1999), and Deus Ex (2000).

Deus Ex was doubtlessly ahead of its time and shares a great deal of the qualities that made Half Life and System Shock 2 superb.

Deus Ex's story is about the choices individuals make concerncing technology, and how those technological choices alter the future in positive and negative ways.

Everything I want in an FPS adventure is present in Deus Ex: The story is intriguing, the gameplay has depth, and the soundtrack is phenomenal.

If you are looking for an old school FPS adventure, Deux Ex is definitely a top choice. There is an easy to use mod that updates the graphics and smoothes them out significantly - highly recommended!

9.5/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fifteen years and some forty save files later I'm STILL finding new things almost every time I open this game. It's amazing that Deus Ex managed to pack enough worthwhile content to make every playthrough feel unique, and not just in the game's scenarios themselves, but how you handle them. Every single weapon and aug has potential to do great things depending on how you build your character, with the exception of extremely situational, one use items like the P2000, or gimmicky augs like the Spybot.

Deus Ex is a game that's hard to compare to others, because of how neatly the package is tied together. It's the way the atmospheric elements like music or even something as simple as lighting combine with the meandering you'll end up doing in the game's hub-worlds, and the hubs are where Deus Ex becomes a completely different expirience. Sure it's fun to play one of the good ol' linear levels with fairly straightforward objectives, but the sprawling, open areas are where the game goes from an explosive action flick to a gritty neo-noir with hours worth of sidequests and aimless exploring. For me, this is what makes Deus Ex so great. It plays off of the best characteristics or all the pieces that put it together.

The soundtrack can easily switch from a fast-paced electronic beat to a faint ambiance to fit each level specifically. which perfectly coincides with combat. In one level you'll be mowing down every NSF soldier you see with a Sawed-Off, and the next you'll be methodically weaving between buildings, hiding from cameras and deciding to silently take down that group of enemies or avoid them all together. The game reinforces this shift between styles with the limited amount of items you can find. Instead of holding you back from entering an area in the game meant for later, it'll slightly nudge you away by guarding it with really tough enemies, or locking the door with a numpad that takes 4 tools to open. It's the small elements that were taken account with the level design in mind, especially with the hubs that elevate the game so much.

While the story starts to sound like the focus group were a bunch of tinfoil-hatted conspiracy theorists, it's all explained so well and in great detail that makes it seem more realistic". There's constantly data being thrown at you that it can be hard to absorb
date: but it creates a scale that really isn't realized until you pay more attention to it. Reading datacubes on tables or emails on a computer will give more insight into what's going on around you
recommended: and more importantly the people involved. Characters you liked early on might become more despicable
hoursPlayed: or vice-versa depending on how much you know about them from those optional little bits of character development that are placed throughout the game.\n\nHell
voteText: this review is just another paper thrown into a file cabinet
helpfulPercent: but it's more of a personal love letter to the expirience I've had with Deus Ex over the course of my life. It seems every 3 or so years after I haven't played it in a while I'll reinstall it and sink another 50 hours into
votesHelpful: and those little things I find that I didn't notice when I was a kid 10 years ago will put a huge smile on my face. It's by no means a perfect game
votesTotal: and it's not the first game to mix different genres in a very similar way (see System Shock)
votesFunny: but it's a game that has to be expirienced first hand to know just how great it is."

reviewText:
Deus Ex really surprised me, in a good way. I underrated this phenomenal stealth-shooter-RPG hybrid at first, because of the terrible graphics and sound.

You play as a cyborg in the future that gets wrapped up in the shadow government when agencies try to seize all government power. The story is built from conspiracy theories. It's ultimately pretty simple, but it works and gives the world an interesting feel.

For each problem in Deus Ex, there are many ways to solve it, and many ways to build your character to take advantage of them. You can gun down enemy bases soldier by soldier, or use non-lethal force to sneak in and out with no casualties. There are many viable options, and this is where the game really shines.

However, the graphics are horrible (even for its time), most of the music isn't very good, and the voice acting is hilariously bad.

I got this really cheap, and I've loved it. I've probably spent a good 40 hours on it, and I can definitely recommend it.

reviewText: This classic, formative RPG is a great deal of fun and should not be missed by any fans of the genre. Sure, everything about it is dated; this is to be expected, given that it was released in 2000. The game's appeal isn't to be found in the graphics or the sound, or whatever else you might find archaic about it, but rather in the brilliant, immersive story and the pure importance that the game held for the future of the genre.\n\nBuy it; you'll have a good time, provided that you manage to be patient through the first hour or so.

reviewText:
Quite simply my personal favorite game. For this title those words have been heard, read, and repeated hundreds of thousands of times over and with good reason. Those looking for a master piece of an experience this is it. Few games understand what elements it wants and how to achieve them quite like the original Deus Ex does.

While graphically the game is somewhat blocky, it still holds up with memorably characters and a strong story ripe to burst with conspiracies mixing in to one another in a cohesive package that will have you curious about what is really going on right until the very last minutes of the game.

Hot off the heels of Thief this title allows for a purely stealth character to the point where characters even acknowledge the use of stealth and lack of a body count in the dialog, and sometimes even reward the player for taking such a route. While its encouraged to not make Duke blush at the amount of corpses and ways to make them, its still an option within the game and a perfectly viable one at that with special abilities known as Augmentations that increase resistence to bullets, or skills that can be trained to perfect aiming. Weapon mods also add to the deadly efficency of guns. Silenced sniper rifles with a laser sight and maxed out accuracy mods in the hands of an expert marksman? Watch the badguys drop to the floor before their friends even figure out what's happening.

How about bypassing security? Get a strength mod and put a dumpster against a wall and simply leap over it, usurping an entire security network of elaborate traps, cameras, and patrols. Perhaps something a little closer down to earth is your style? Then crawl into a vent and ensure you're not caught by guard. Feeling like you want to be a little tricky? Have pepper spray in hand? Spray that in the path of a laser beam and quickly crawl passed it as you block the beam without alerting the guards.

All of this wrapped into a setting so rarely explored, Cyberpunk, and the game is a treat for any tech enthusist to go what if" with. Those looking for the definitive Ghost in the Shell experience
date: look no further and enjoy.\n\nOn a personal note; this is a game I come back to and play to competion at least once every year and there is almost always something new that I experience in some fashion
recommended: be it through gameplay or dialog. I strongly advise against looking up guides or tricks beyond the ones mentioned above that are less intuitive and not an easy few to discover on your own.\n\nHint: Open the credits and type: "thereisnospoon" without the quotes and enjoy the effects once in game."

reviewText: Possibly my favourite game of all time. An incredibly deep, immersive FPS/RPG with a rich story, memorable characters and an amazing variation on playstyles. I have completed this game so many times I have lost count, yet each time I discover something new that I hadn't seen before. The games dialogue reacts to everything you do, whether you kill people on sight or simply knock them out, whether you remain hidden or run out in plain view, obey orders or find your own way, how much exploring you do, how much you interact with others. Each time changing the dialogue and story in subtle ways. It's stealth system was one of the most robust for it's day, very much focussing on sticking to the shadows and staying low behind cover. However you may decide to become a literally bulletproof death machine, wielding rifles, swords, rocket launchers and more with equal ferocity.\nDefinitely worth the purchase. A classic game with a mature, well researched story on the possible future.

reviewText:
This game, guys. This game. Those screenshots up there? Yeah, that's how dated the graphics are. It was released in 2000. The gameplay, on the other hand, is a standard-setter for the RPGFPS genre.

Never played Deus Ex? This is your chance. Get ready to be tactical about your entrances. Plan it out a little before you fire off a shot, or don't shoot at all. You can be stealthy! You can hack that door! You can bash that other one down and shoot people! The Deus Ex series' level design alone sets a standard. Sure, you have exact goals to get to. You have about a dozen ways to get to each one, however, and the harder you have to look, the better it generally is for your health bar.

The weapon spread is realistic. Didn't put any points into using that kind of gun? You're going to have to stand there for a while to be able to land your shot, or you'll miss the broad side of a barn in broad daylight. Put ALL of your points into using that kind of gun? Give it about one second. Yep, headshot.

I will admit. There is no recharge for your augments' energy supply, nor is there any health regen. You have to find items to recharge your energy, and medkits for your health. But that's part of the charm of these old shooters. You don't just sit there patiently and undo all of your mistakes. You play through it right. Not all that hard to do so, though, they do have some pretty darned easy difficulty settings and a quicksave button.

The dialogue is not this game's strong point. Oh well. The story itself is good regardless.

The optional objectives, as is the norm for Deus Ex, are highly rewarding to carry out. <spoiler redacted> to complete the optional objective in the first mission and you'll see how lucrative it can be.

On a scale of six to potato, this game is... Y2K Standards Raiser. And at the time I'm writing this, it's seven dollars. The campaign will take you a lot longer to beat than I've put into it. It's worth the seven dollars. Did I mention there's an incredible number of mods for it? No? Damn. Best part. There's mods for it.

reviewText:
TL;DR~  Look past the dated graphics and play it like an RPG.  GET IT.

This is a game that I've owned several times since 2001, but I could never get into it.  The pacing seemed slow, and the lack of ammo just wasn't fun for me...   I was playing like a shooter.

Fast forward to 2013.  I decided to play this after getting it in a Deus Ex bundle,  and holy crap I was surprised.  The game I remembered was a clunky shooter with crappy guns... ( Honestly, I felt the same way about Mass Effect when it first came out.  )  I see now that it's an inteligent rpg with an action mask.   I was rewarded for being cautious, investing skill points in non-combat abilities, and using non-lethal approaches.  Also, the story is actually good~

reviewText: It seems kind of unfair to review a living legend. Imagine if someone asked you to critique Tetris. What would say? It would be hard not to look at things through rose colored glasses. Luckily, I had only heard that Deus Ex was great when I first picked it up. I wasn't a fanboy, I didn't really care, even though I had played and enjoyed Human Revolution. And when I got my hands on it, oh boy. Everyone was right.\nDeus Ex is fantastic. Like, the type of fantastic that doesn't exist anymore. Imagine a game that accounts for everything the player can do. Deus Ex is just short of that, and only fails to be utterly perfect because it hasn't aged well. There are no autosaves even though there really should be. The voice acting can be horrid. An automatic inventory sort would've been nice. Deus Ex has tiny problems that are really only caused by being a product of a different time. All in all, unlike I a lot of people, I still don't think Deus Ex is the greatest game ever.....(read comments)

reviewText:
An exquisite, futuristic,  sci-fi masterpiece. So many titles that fall by the wayside never standing the test of time, yet Deus Ex remains over the ash heap of long forgotten games.

To me what made this game so appealing is the universe in which it exists. A future that could easily be our own with the technology, conspiracy theories and similar named global powers that have had an effect on the real world we experience today.  Often if you took the time within the game to read information about current events happening and the parallels between our worlds it often seemed prophetic. That makes this game all the more intriguing and a satisfying experience.

Character interactions also shaped the way you approach the game throughout. Do I try to talk my way out? Do I try to sneak in to accomplish my objective or go in guns blazing? Depending on the type of playstyle you want, you could distibute your skills and augmentations in specific ways so that your enemies would barely know you were there and if they did, it would be too late.

Such an awesome game..I would definitely recommend this game to fans who love a futuristic, dystopian, and cyberpunk universe. You will not be disappointed.

reviewText: There are plenty of genres where you could lament the absence of good games and the FPS genre is certainly not one of them. reviewText:
I've been meaning to play DE1 for the past few years, given that I have heard so many good things about it, but I was too busy playing other games. Regardless, given the fact that this game is available on Steam (and was only about $5 when I bought it, can't beat such a deal), I decided that it's finally time to give it a try. And so I did, being extremely impressed with the game. My knowledge of older (2000 and prior) game titles is limited to MS-DOS games like Wolfenstein 3D, Commander Keen, Doom, Quake, Blake Stone, etc., and as such I didn't play anything like Deus Ex or System Shock, or other important games of this time. I am stating this because I am making it clear that I have absolutely nothing to compare DE1 to.

With that said, this really is a phenomenal game. As plenty of other people have said already, the amount of ways to get past a certain mission, being able to do things at your own pace instead of being forced into a linear storyline type of game is quite refreshing. It's not quite an open-world game, but that's completely understandable. The lore of DE1 is unparalleled in video game history, in my opinion. It's the kind of game that comes along once in a lifetime, blows everyone and their mother away in sheer disbelief, and is never matched in overall quality (at least in its genre, though one can argue that it has its own genre, again making it unsuitable for comparison to other games).

The bottom line is that I really can't find anything wrong with this game. I waited way too long to play it, but it's better late than never. Others have claimed that it would probably be more enjoyable to have played DE1 in its prime (the year 2000 where there was little or no competition in that regard), but as I've already said, this game hasn't quite been surpassed by anything. Therefore, I don't believe that it makes a difference whether you play this game in its heyday or (almost) 15 years later. This is a highly excellent game that I'll recommend to anyone, and the fact that it runs on very much any computer made in the last ten years (even netbooks), makes it even more accessible. 5 out of 5 stars for this game.

reviewText:
Immservie Sci-Fi RPG from the First Person perspective, involving detailed gulfs of skill trees, upgrades , augmentations, along with  dynamic story and character development.

The in-game establishment of the lore and attention to world and story detail is incredibly crafted and remains intriguing and compelling to this day, 15 years after it's release.

Sure, the writers maybe watched The Matrix and The X-Files a little too much.

And the main character sounds like he's wearing high heels.

But overall, Deus Ex is an Opus of gaming, a masterpiece that seemingly allows you, the player to see your personality reflected back at you in the way the world reacts to your presence  and how the story unfolds, according to your own choices and actions.

In my opinion, the greatest game ever made.

Play it.

reviewText: Deus Ex is just one of those games you need to learn to like. When first tried to play this, I really didn't like the game because I thought it was too cheap and confusing. But after a few more tries the game finally clicked and then I started liking, and once you learn how to like this game, trust me it's probably one of the best games you have ever played after that. What I think makes it heard for people to like it at first is that the game is not what it looks like. To most people it looks like a FPS shooter(which to an extent it is, but I'll get to more about that later), therefore people play the game like it's an FPS(Guns Blazing) and expect everything else to work. That's where you then realize what it really is. Deus Ex is actually a First Person RPG. To begin with, Exploration is very important in this game, and I'd say you have to do it in order to get info to open doors or get more important information to the story, plus you get points from exploring. Also while Deus Ex is in First Person and seems like a FPS Shooter, it's not that really. To begin with going in Guns Blazing will alert guards, in which they can lock a door, sound an alarm to atract more guards, and can use explosives. Therefore Stealth gameplay is much better suited for this game, as your chances of survival and completing your objective is more possible. Also Deus Ex's gunplay is kinda bad, therefore even if you do go guns blazing, the gunplay doesn't work well with you. Now another important thing is that you really need to listen to what NPC's say, as it is actually important to the story(in a another more important way which I won't spoil) and plus they might say some important tactics which can help. One last thing is that the story is affected by what choices you make, for example you can actually choose to kill a certain character if you want, which significantly changes the story. And before I go, the Story for this game is very intersting. It brings up many philshoical and poltical points about corruption, what is right, and more.\nOverall I'm more than gald to recommend this game, but just remember this game has a steep learning curve.

reviewText:
*EDIT*

Now that i fully finished the game, i get why it's constantly in the top spot or contending for it on all list of top games, it's purely art. 16 years later with what's now considered crappy visuals, laughable voice acting, ugly combat, it still tops out. There's something magical about it, the story, the constant acts of betrayal, down to the choices you have to make, it was a thrilling and enjoyable ride that i would definetely reccomend to anyone interested in rpgs, fps, or just general story telling. A must own game.





Only 5 hours into the game and holy ♥♥♥♥ i'm overwhelmed. I kind of regret never playing it before.

This game offers pretty much everything you want in a tactical fps whether you want to go head-on combat (Which isn't encouraged by your higher officers) or a full on stealth gameplay with lockpicking, hacking, finding new paths by exploration, negotiating with people, reading notes and so many other ways.

Even for a 2000 game in my opinion it still looks nice, the enviroment is well done, the music is great, lots of variety in weapons and items with almost everything having a use.

Well, can't wait to see what else this game has to offer, to be updated.

reviewText: It's a classic everyone should play by the time they're 30, if they're interested in gaming at all. The gameplay still holds up beautifully, if not the graphics. There are just so many fun, creative, flexible ways to take out your opponents with them being none the wiser. I don't mean flexible like Sam Fisher doing splits either, but Sam would kill for half of JC Denton's tech. The game even lets you bypass most enemies without engaging, or to set yourself up to Rambo some baddies. The story is also relatively deep and nuanced. I don't want to spoil anything in case you ever get the itch to play this gem. If you're interested in game design, definitely check this one out even more so. Then you too can fail miserably trying to live up to the best stealth-fps-action-rpg-and-probably-some-other-bits ever. 5/5

reviewText: There are plenty of genres where you could lament the absence of good games and the FPS genre is certainly not one of them. There are however few games much like Deus Ex and this is a real shame. Deus Ex not only makes an excellent and lengthy FPS, it makes for an excellent and deep story driven RPG experience too. A focus on just one would have made a good game and it is a testament to just how great Deus Ex is that they have been combined so successfully into an even better one. Even if neither of the genres is of interest to you, you should at least try Deus Ex to see if this wonderful fusion can’t change your mind.

reviewText:
My first exposure to Deus Ex came with the PS2 port back in high school, and I am happy to say, after a few hours of playing the PC version (with the graphics fix that is very, very necessary if you're planning on playing anything other than a slideshow whenever water's around), that my fondness for the game is not due entirely to my nostalgia goggles. The game is by no means a good-looking piece of software, but the atmosphere is brilliantly realized, and the overall feel of the world is absolutely masterfully done.

You will certainly want to rebind the controls (especially F12 (which is your flashlight by default) unless you've already changed the Steam screenshot keybind), and it might take a bit of time to get back into the turn-of-the-century control scheme, but this game is well worth revisiting, or visiting for the first time.

Rarely does a game feel this cohesive. Glory be, glory be...

reviewText:
I've been meaning to play DE1 for the past few years, given that I have heard so many good things about it, but I was too busy playing other games. Regardless, given the fact that this game is available on Steam (and was only about $5 when I bought it, can't beat such a deal), I decided that it's finally time to give it a try. And so I did, being extremely impressed with the game. My knowledge of older (2000 and prior) game titles is limited to MS-DOS games like Wolfenstein 3D, Commander Keen, Doom, Quake, Blake Stone, etc., and as such I didn't play anything like Deus Ex or System Shock, or other important games of this time. I am stating this because I am making it clear that I have absolutely nothing to compare DE1 to.

With that said, this really is a phenomenal game. As plenty of other people have said already, the amount of ways to get past a certain mission, being able to do things at your own pace instead of being forced into a linear storyline type of game is quite refreshing. It's not quite an open-world game, but that's completely understandable. The lore of DE1 is unparalleled in video game history, in my opinion. It's the kind of game that comes along once in a lifetime, blows everyone and their mother away in sheer disbelief, and is never matched in overall quality (at least in its genre, though one can argue that it has its own genre, again making it unsuitable for comparison to other games).

The bottom line is that I really can't find anything wrong with this game. I waited way too long to play it, but it's better late than never. Others have claimed that it would probably be more enjoyable to have played DE1 in its prime (the year 2000 where there was little or no competition in that regard), but as I've already said, this game hasn't quite been surpassed by anything. Therefore, I don't believe that it makes a difference whether you play this game in its heyday or (almost) 15 years later. This is a highly excellent game that I'll recommend to anyone, and the fact that it runs on very much any computer made in the last ten years (even netbooks), makes it even more accessible. 5 out of 5 stars for this game.

reviewText: It's very hard to not recommend Deus Ex, it came from a time when the RPG genre was at it's strongest and nearly beat em' all, it was completely unrivaled in terms of gameplay and depth until Morrowind stepped into the ring and took it's belt. The quality of the game however will force anyone with a fully functional brain to quickly forget about the awful graphics. If you want the best RPG of all time, and swords/magic aren't your thing, Deus Ex is more than a worthy second place.\n\n9/10

reviewText:
Deus Ex is a hard game to review. The game has a devout following of fans heralding it as 'the best game ever made', and even 14 years after the original release and 2 sequels many have not move that title to another game. While the guise of nostalgia may blind many to the errors of their loved titles of the past I did not play this game until about 2010 (which is considerably recent considering that this game was already 10 years old by that time). Through my experience playing it I believe that Deus Ex deserves much of the reverence it receives.
From the moment of starting a new game you can see why Deus Ex is often held as one of gaming's greatest titles. From the conspiracy laden cyberpunk setting filled with a dark aesthetic and an ambient soundtrack that becomes more intense when being perused by an enemy this game sets tone well even by today's standards (If you can get over ten antiquated graphics that is). Though the setting and story are a strong suit I will not spoil them for you, for you should experience them yourself. Though setting and ambiance are all good, gameplay is really where Deus Ex truly shines.
From the beginning you are able to see how much freedom Deus Ex gives the player for a First Person Shooter. Upon starting a new character the player is able to distribute skills to the places they see as suiting themselves. A player can focus on wielding a number of weapons, they can focus on stealth, they can focus on one particular skill, or they can focus on open as many pathways as possible. This freedom is not just a gimmick, but it is echoed in the level design. The player is given the choice at the start to be given a sniper to take down targets long range, an electric prod for a non-lethal approach, or a GEP gun to take down armored targets. They are also given a number of ways to approach the first mission which they must find an execute themselves. The player may run in guns blazing (Though they will probably fail), they may silently take down targets and climb boxes for a shortcut towards their goal, or they may may sneak in undetected without violence, they may retrieve a key for a secret exit, all of which is up for their discovery. Deus Ex is designed to give players a number of options so that no matter how the build their character they are able to play to their strengths. They can even later augment their character to buff their weaknesses or enhance their strengths. All of this is because Deus Ex is not simply a First-Person Shooter, it is an RPG. From character dialogue trees to experience to item hoarding to digging for information in a surprisingly well written world, Deus Ex brings the best of what RPG's have to offer and wraps them in the skin of a difficult early 2000's FPS. Though, the early 2000's part may be seen as less than a boon to many.
Although the game may not have aged so well. Don't get me wrong, I very much enjoyed my time with Deus Ex, but the game is still 14 years old. Textures are blurry, the models are edgy, loading points in levels are short but frequent, animations are primitive, the lighting is hardly there, the controls are more ancient than many choose to remember in their default layout, the AI isn't always too keen, and the voice acting can even be painfully bad to some, though it does run without error on modern PC's as far as I've seen. Even with mods and updates most of the edges remain un-smoothed, and as such the experience may be tainted for many newcomers, especially for those not prepared for a difficulty that would today be commonly viewed as obscene were it not for the release and popularity of titles like Super Meat Boy and Dark Souls.
If you can get through the fact that Deus Ex is an old title it will be absolutely worth your time and money. Even though I didn't grow up with it, I still enjoyed the hours I put in enough to declare it as one of my favorite games. My review is incomplete, and if this sounds enticing to you I highly recommend you try it yourself.

reviewText: Deus Ex is both my favorite game and arguably the greatest PC game of all time. It appears frequently at or near the top of best ever lists by both journalists and the gaming public. It was ranked #1 of the top 100 PC games of all time by PC Gamer, PC gaming's most widely respected publication.\n\nThese accolades are no surprise when one sees how brilliantly the game succeeds on so many levels. The story is a masterfully crafted, globe-hopping cyberpunk adventure through which the player's character navigates a dystopian future world on a mission to unravel a Gordian Knot of conspiracies, secrets and lies. Both the player's character and the world he inhabits are shaped by nanotechnology, the former for better, the latter for worse. The player assumes the role of JC Denton, an agent of UNATCO, an international anti-terrorism organization. The terror he combats is largely attributable to the Gray Death, a nanomechanical virus that has ravaged the planet. Denton, however, is immune to the virus thanks to nano-augmentation, a cutting-edge technology available only to elite government agents. Nano-augmentation endows Denton with an array of superhuman powers such as infrared vision and invisibility. Augmentations may be customized to suit a particular playing style, for example stealth artists may opt for the footstep-silencing lower body augmentation while aggressive circle-strafing gunners can choose increased speed. The game's augmentations perfectly complement the open-ended design that is its greatest feature of all. Every level features secret areas for circumventing enemies, gathering intel or finding resources. These avenues might be accessible only with certain abilities, for example a fence might be surmountable only to players with the speed-boosting aug that allows them to leap it or the strength-boosting aug that allows them to stack enough heavy crates to climb it. Every mission can be approached in multiple ways using stealth, force, diplomacy or a combination of the three. The story itself actually adapts to the ramifications of the player's approach to the missions. The game is so open-ended, in fact, that there are only two required neutralizations. It can played as a straight-up run-and-gun shooter, a sneak-through-the-shadows stealth adventure or anywhere in between. Further complementing the open-ended gameplay is the RPG-style stat system in which players can develop proficiency in certain weapons or skills such as hacking, lockpicking, or even swimming. This level of freedom was unprecedented in shooters at the time of the game's release. Before, such games would tell the player  Go here

reviewText:
Deus Ex! A Nanopunk/Cyberpunk themed action role playing game, combining first person shooter, stealth and role playing elements.

Developed by ION Storm and Published by Eidos Interactive/SQUARE ENIX and designed by Warren Spector and Harvey Smith.

Set in a dystopian world druing the year 2052 the plot follows UNATCO Agent JC Denton to combat terrorist forces. As the plot thickens Denton becomes entangled in a dark and deep ancient conspiracy.

A game that has received universal acclaim and recieved multiple awards!

The games storyline is unmatched by any other, the blending of genres: Role-playing, FPS, Adventure and Immersive Simulation makes this game the greatest of all time. Touches a lot on world affairs and it really takes a hold of you throwing you into dark and deep government conspiracies

Good:
-The story is truly amazing it will overpower you!
-The gameplay incoporates four genres and it blends together perfectly
-Expansive environments with a lot of exploration.
-Dialogue and back story improves the overall experience and there are some funny and cheesy one liners from NPCs.
-RPG Elements are designed very well
-The soundtrack of Deus Ex is flawless! The music really adds to the experience and the atmosphere, with subtle ambient street music to blasting bass/electronic tracks in combat.
-Highly replayable I have played through at least 10 times.
-The games graphics although not amazing really add to the atmosphere of a dark world which really puts Deus Ex into context.

Bad:
-Nothing, this game is flawless.

There will never be a game in my heart that will replace this masterpiece of a game!

Worth the experience, worth the penny, worth playing at least ten times!

10 Foxes out of 10 Foxes :D

reviewText:
Deus Ex. Need I say more?
The definition of PC gaming, and an Icon of gaming as a whole.
Smart story, interesting characters, well written dialogue, and an atmospheric world. After 20 minutes, the now jarring graphics of 2000 won't seem so bad once the world sucks you in.

One of the few games that's simply easy to get lost in, and after letting it absorb you for so long, you'll feel empty once you beat it.

reviewText:
Fifteen years and some forty save files later I'm STILL finding new things almost every time I open this game. It's amazing that Deus Ex managed to pack enough worthwhile content to make every playthrough feel unique, and not just in the game's scenarios themselves, but how you handle them. Every single weapon and aug has potential to do great things depending on how you build your character, with the exception of extremely situational, one use items like the P2000, or gimmicky augs like the Spybot.

Deus Ex is a game that's hard to compare to others, because of how neatly the package is tied together. It's the way the atmospheric elements like music or even something as simple as lighting combine with the meandering you'll end up doing in the game's hub-worlds, and the hubs are where Deus Ex becomes a completely different expirience. Sure it's fun to play one of the good ol' linear levels with fairly straightforward objectives, but the sprawling, open areas are where the game goes from an explosive action flick to a gritty neo-noir with hours worth of sidequests and aimless exploring. For me, this is what makes Deus Ex so great. It plays off of the best characteristics or all the pieces that put it together.

The soundtrack can easily switch from a fast-paced electronic beat to a faint ambiance to fit each level specifically. which perfectly coincides with combat. In one level you'll be mowing down every NSF soldier you see with a Sawed-Off, and the next you'll be methodically weaving between buildings, hiding from cameras and deciding to silently take down that group of enemies or avoid them all together. The game reinforces this shift between styles with the limited amount of items you can find. Instead of holding you back from entering an area in the game meant for later, it'll slightly nudge you away by guarding it with really tough enemies, or locking the door with a numpad that takes 4 tools to open. It's the small elements that were taken account with the level design in mind, especially with the hubs that elevate the game so much.

While the story starts to sound like the focus group were a bunch of tinfoil-hatted conspiracy theorists, it's all explained so well and in great detail that makes it seem more realistic". There's constantly data being thrown at you that it can be hard to absorb
date: but it creates a scale that really isn't realized until you pay more attention to it. Reading datacubes on tables or emails on a computer will give more insight into what's going on around you
recommended: and more importantly the people involved. Characters you liked early on might become more despicable
hoursPlayed: or vice-versa depending on how much you know about them from those optional little bits of character development that are placed throughout the game.\n\nHell

reviewText:
Hands done one of the greatest FPS/RPG mixes of all time, as well as one of the best overall games of all time. Two things make this game especially good: the story and the gameplay. The augmentations that you use to add new abilites really drastically change the ways you can approach situations instead of just adding passive bonuses like most perk-like systems in so many other RPGs. Each problem you encounter has a dozen ways of solving it and can be solved by any type of character build, so each player can play through the game in their own unique style. Combat has this aspect as well, as you level up your skills with different weapon types, so you can play as a sharpshooting sniper or a rocket-launcher weilding maniac. Without having to explain every game mechanic, all you need to know is that the gameplay is deep, complex, and can be enjoyed basically however you want.

While the actual plot line isn't the best, it's the underlying themes that really make it stand out. Not a lot of games ask the types of questions that Deus Ex asks. How much control should the government have on the people? If people were left to govern themselves, would the good side of humanity win over the evil side, or is man's hunger for power and control too great? What does it mean to be human? Are machines more perfect than man? It's a very philosophical game, and it's great to see different, distinct endings that aren't black-and-white in their morality, they all present different governing philosophies, and it's up to the player to decide which they think is the best as they play through the game.

The only drawbacks to the game are the awful voice acting, dodgy engine and the shoddy graphics. However, if you're going to prevent yourself from playing this game because of the poor graphics (even for 2000) and the engine hiccups, your really shouldn't. Particularly with this game as it's rightfully a classic and should be played by anybody who enjoys RPG's, FPS's, or both.

reviewText:
The 1990's culminated in three monumental titles that undeniably would shape the FPS adventure genre for years to come: Half Life (1998), System Shock 2 (1999), and Deus Ex (2000).

Deus Ex was doubtlessly ahead of its time and shares a great deal of the qualities that made Half Life and System Shock 2 superb.

Deus Ex's story is about the choices individuals make concerncing technology, and how those technological choices alter the future in positive and negative ways.

Everything I want in an FPS adventure is present in Deus Ex: The story is intriguing, the gameplay has depth, and the soundtrack is phenomenal.

If you are looking for an old school FPS adventure, Deux Ex is definitely a top choice. There is an easy to use mod that updates the graphics and smoothes them out significantly - highly recommended!

9.5/10

There is a problem with this game running too fast on modern computers(dialogue finished before actually done, player moves too fast, etc.) and a problem with low fps, but check the community hub for discussions about it, there are many good mods to fix this.

reviewText:
Just as perfect as everyone says it is.

You probably don't need me to sum it up for you, as I'm sure many other people have summed this game up far better in the 16 years it's been out for. To put it bluntly, Deus Ex is a stealth game, and a damn good one, at that. It offers an unprecedented amount of freedom and lets you take on your objectives in whatever way you want, or just not at all.

So many unexpected consequences and little variations, multiple playstyles and different augmentations to support each one mean that every playthrough can be completely different.

The only real problem is the AI. They're forgetful and seem to lack basic combat sense. Also, the tiny inconvenience of not being able to move a body without looting it. I don't want to have to clear room in my inventory to pick up a flamethrower that I'm not using so I can move a body.

Other than that, the game lets you play completely non-lethally with the exception of having to glitch past one boss, which is actually really fun.

That's about it, I guess. The game mechanics still hold up very well and the story is even more engaging than most modern games, so Deus Ex gets a 10/10. Would play again, many times. As long as I don't have to deal with those ♥♥♥♥ing spiderbots. ♥♥♥♥ those things. Oh, and the ♥♥♥♥ing greasels. ♥♥♥♥ them too.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Old but gold.

Especially for a game that is over 15 years old.

Definitely buy this.  For 7 bucks, you get one hell of a ride as an international cop in a globe-trekking adventure in a mid-21st century world where millions die from an unknown plague and active civil war in 'stable' Western countries push society closer and closer to the brink.

Although certain gameplay elements, in particular AI behavior ('Duh, my buddy five feet away just started yelling about cops and started shooting, let me continue my patrol - oh wait it's that cop!') and graphics date the game somewhat, the story and atmosphere/level design rivals that of more celebrated franchises today.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
An absolute classic, a must-have for any self respecting PC gamer.

That being said, it's not perfect - the graphics quite frankly are pretty bad, the textures mainly consist of concrete and metal, and the NPCs all look basically the same. Also, there's no auto-save system, which messed me up a few times when I forgot to quicksave for a while.

However, the gameplay is amazing, very rewarding and fulfilling, and gives the player a lot of freedom to play however they want. Choices and actions you make, no matter how small, actually have consequences that can reach far into the game's story. On the subject of the story, it's absolute gold, as are the character development and interactions (although the voice acting can be hilariously bad). Music is god-tier, seriously some of the best music I've heard in a game, even to this day.

Overall if you can look past the visual flaws then you'll discover a real gem in Deus Ex. Plus it's fairly cheap. There really is no reason you shouldn't have played this.

reviewText: Literally one of the best video games I've ever played. It combines stealth, RPG, cyberpunk, and action so perfectly. Also, I know you're suppose to use stealth, but my God, it'll take you twenty rounds of assault rifle ammo to his skull to even dent an enemy's health bar. But besides the laughable voice actor, moments where you can barely know what to do, and overpowered enemies, this game is dead near perfect and you should play it.

reviewText: If you can get past the bad graphics and clunky combat you will find one of the most unique and enjoyable gameplay experiences. I played this game in 2015 and still found it to be extremely compelling. The level design is excellent. There is true freedom of choice that effects the story. Side characters and side missions are extremely enjoyable. The design of this game is nothing short of incredible. The story is very enjoyable and even though the game is so old i found my self on the edge of my seat to see what the next twist is. The world is so immersive and well developed and I really feel you would be doing yourslef a disservice by passing this one up. The game is also pretty cheep for the amount of content. Doing only one story route the game is going to last around 20 hours and this game is not very expensive. There is also a mod that improves some of graphic assets if the bad graphics really bother you. Finally not to be forgotten this game has one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard period. The soundtrack is really amazing and even if you do not play the game go listen to it on youtube it's awesome. Seriouls this game is a classic and should be played by all fans of rpgs and shooters.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I've played, and I've played and finished it in 2016, 16 years after its release. I first played Human Revolution. Whilst the hacking system is better in HR, this original game is also fantastic.

There are multiple ways of playing this game, but you'll find you get more satisfaction from playing stealthy. Don't worry if you don't, you won't be penalised for it. You can play it as an action shooter if you like. The reason I clocked up 40 hours on one play through is mainly because I'd reloaded if I wasn't happy with my play style, or if I messed up my stealth.

The augmentations are a blast! The Ai's pretty funny as well.

I'd recommended this game to fans of Metal Gear Solid, Splinter Cell, and BioShock. Even Half-Life fans would enjoy this because of it's story. The RPG elements are simply that, you don't need to go around grinding to level up or anything.

The lore and the story of this game are spot on. The world isn't thrown in your face, it's yours to explore, and the story is enough. I get irritated with a lot of games now trying to be action movies. This game doesn't do that, it's a good honest title.

TAKE NOTE:
Make sure you safe frequently and often -- don't rely on binding quick saves. Mine corrupted, and it seems a common issue. Make manual saves, I'm afraid e.g. <level name> suffixed with 'after guards', 'before aug', etc. I had gigabytes worth -- they take up a lot of space!

reviewText:
DEUS EX - Every time you mention it, someone will reinstall it.

Three years after I first played Deus Ex: Human Revolution and enjoyed it immensely, it was finally time for its big brother. I tried the original Deus Ex a few years ago, but I just couldn't get passed its outdated visuals (including New Vision) and especially its awful animations. Which I think is probably typical for the Deus Ex series, since Human Revolution also wasn't a looker to begin with. But I suppose I kinda matured in terms of gaming in the last two years, because when I started Deus Ex again a few months ago, the visuals didn't bother me.

But enough about me. Besides the convincing dystopia future with its own share of society problems dripping with atmosphere, I needed some time to adjust to the gameplay. Because it has been quite some time that a game didn't spoon-fed me how to play the game or which way to go with a huge pointer on-screen. Overwhelming at first, but the level of player freedom makes you comfortable very quickly. You get a relatively big area each level where you can go where ever you please, do whatever you want in a manner you find appropriate. The excellent level designs makes sure of that. Later on, based on the augmentations you choose, you get even more options that suit your play style. No wrongs or rights.

+ Excellent level design, a lot of player freedom, all roads lead to Rome.
+ Not a single moment of holding hands, just good ol' fashioned exploration and finding the way on your own.
+ Dystopia cyberpunk future and its problems are represented very well and convincing.
+ A great story to boot that rarely to never loses its grip.
+ A lot of choices and consequences that can make your life later on easier or harder.
+ Great atmosphere and an even better soundtrack.

- Ugly face animations, probably even for 2000 standards.
- Mediocre/static voice acting, except Bob Page whom I thought sounded excellent.
- Stupid AI, though understandable considering it's 15 years old now.

I still prefer Human Revolution (first love and all that), but now I can understand where most of its brilliance comes from. If the next Deus Ex, Mankind Divided, can combine the strengths from both Deus Ex 1 and Human Revolution, and somehow iron out their respective little flaws, Mankind Divided will be a very, very unforgettable experience. The hype is real.

9/10

reviewText: There are three endings, in which your choice literally determines the fate of the world; it’s remarkable how the writers managed to concoct such a situation from which three very different outcomes could emerge. And it’s genuinely difficult to choose, when the time comes (and unlike a lot of games I could mention, the conditions for each ending are very clear-cut). I went with my gut feeling just as I did the first time I finished the game all those years ago, picking a kind of benevolent dictatorship, which meant turning my back on an old friend. And I felt genuinely bad for betraying him, for derailing his most worthy intentions. When a game can elicit that kind of emotion for a character who is a few lines of code, some sound files and a 3D model, that’s probably about when you’re hitting the magic criteria of art.

reviewText:
Deus Ex is often claimed to be the best game in computer game history. Personally I agree but it's not without it's problems. Join me while I take a look at this critically praised title.

The Story
Deus Ex begins in the docks of the island where the statue of liberty is located at. The island is under lockdown because of a terrorist attack by an organization called NSF" that has managed to overtake the entire island. You are "JC" Denton
date:
a nano augmented super agent working for the security agency UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition) and your task is to infiltrate the statue of liberty and capture the leader of the terrorist attack alive. You meet up with your brother: Paul Denton which gives you a weapon and the location of a contact that can help JC into the statue. JC is later tasked with working under the supervision of his machine augmented collegue Anna Navarre in several tasks related to attacks against the NSF.

The story has no problem introducing new characters to you. All the major characters you meets are colorful and memorable but most of all they feel real.

Level Design
When you exit the docks you come across patrolling terrorists pretty much instantly. How you prefer to go up to the tower of liberty is entirely up to you as there are a number of ways to do so. The level design in this very first level is optimized to be as open as possible with plenty of secrets so it makes newcomers confused as to where to start and how to approach the problem. If you search around you will find to be able to get the Sniper rifle and the Crossbow on the very first level of the game.

The other levels in the game varies with open areas and enclosed areas but they're never entirely linear. They are more often than not full of branching paths but of course there are a few linear levels which JC has to venture though but even those can be progressed through in different ways
recommended: making for a truly varied experience. Almost all levels in the game allows for a subtle approach (or even several) but a direct assault approach is never out of the question either. However
hoursPlayed: the game rewards subtle approaches more than lethal ones which is apparent even in the first few levels of the game.\n\nThere is however one level that I want to bring up
voteText:
directly before you arrive in Hong Kong - where you need to rescue your helicopter from a hangar of some sort: While not being a bad level in it's own right - this level did not add anything to the game and felt entirely unnecessary to me.

RPG Elements
JC Denton starts out with a couple of skill points which he invests in different skills. These are in several different areas ranging from very useful to merely a convenience. The developers are aware of the convenience skills and they cost a lot less than the more essential skills that you can invest in. So if you want to be able to be a great swimmer it will not cost as much as being a good hacker or a good shooter but it will still cost something. Even if you don't have any skills in the different areas you will still be able to do these tasks - albeit at a higher cost of the resources to carry out the tasks. For example you might come across a locked door. If you are untrained in lockpicking you will only be able to unlock 10 points (of a universal maximum of 100) from the lock per lockpick. As the tools of these trades are relatively difficult to acquire large numbers of and locked doors being plentiful this skill easily turns out to be one of the most useful ones. So if you're untrained you will merely have to be more selective in the doors you want to try and unlock. If you run out you can also sometimes just blow up the door with explosives but the explosives in this game is even more rare than lockpicks. Unlike lockpicks though - explosives mostly only need 1 charge to succeed.

Deus Ex also features an "augmentation" system where you get to choose between different buffs and abilities JC will permanently be outfitted with during the game. JC can choose between being better at smashing peoples skulls in with melee weapons or lifting heavy boxes and crates. One allows JC to take people down in one hit and the other allows him to bring cover or trap people. You also get other kinds of abilities like being able to either be invisible to people or to cameras or being able to see details of your target (like health and weapons) or have night & heat vision. You always have to choose between two augmentations that works in similar ways but they also need to be upgraded and upgrading is something I think the game could have done without; because without the need to upgrade
helpfulPercent:
augmentations could have been playing a larger role (especially in the early parts of the game) instead of being a bonus on top of JC's more useful Skills system.

Combat and Stealth
Because this is an RPG - Deus Ex's combat changes according to the skills JC acquires during the game. The game favors silent takedowns as the game isn't afraid of pitting you against several enemies at once
votesHelpful: but in a way it is possible to try and engage the enemy with lethal weapons as well but perhaps not as rewarding. Eventually though JC pretty much needs to equip himself with some form of lethal weapons due to the increase of armored enemies during the later stages of the game. This oddly enough gives a sense of progression and a strange dynamic to the fights where you have to use the less lethal weapons against human grunts and the lethal ones against the tougher ones.\n\nThere is one strange thing with Deus Ex's aiming system where you have to crouch in order to get maximum accuracy. It's mainly a way to allow players who doesn't have good fighting skills to still be able to defeat someone with a gun. The games has some other
votesTotal:
more desirable options open for such players such as throwing grenades and using pepper spray.

Of course sneaking is the greatest asset to JC and you don't have to skill up in order to be a great ninja in this game. In fact: JC starts as a pretty good ninja right from the start. As long as the player sticks to the shadows or behind the enemy he's not going to be able to see JC coming and be entirely in the mercy of the players whims.

Conclusion
Deus Ex does have it's problems
votesFunny: just like every single other game but somehow what Deus Ex tries really works. The story
commentsCount: despite it's weaknesses is ultimately very good. The pacing is brisk and you're never without any goals. The level design ranks as one of the best in games up to this point. And unlike so many other games from 2000 this game actually looks really good. Much of what isn't done very good or great is at least solid and the game has very few apparent weaknesses.\n\nMost games I play have quirks that makes the experience playing them somewhat worse by being central mechanics. Deus Ex's problems are very minor in comparison of it's qualities. The augmentation system that I mentioned earlier is after all "a bonus" since JC's power really comes from his skills system. That's why I believe Deus Ex is as great as gaming has ever gotten and deserve a 6 out of 6."
